16502.name: Clash of Empires
boardgameexpansion: Clash of Empires: Fire on the Iser
16502.description:
This is a miniatures wargames(using cardboard cut ups as miniatures) set in the Austro Prussian war of 1866.

Published by Total Fighting Power Games

Expanded by:

Clash of Empires: Fire on the Iser

16503.name: Civil War Pigs
16503.description: This light-hearted game adapts the War with Plastic Infantry Guys (P.I.G.s) rule system to the period of the American Civil War. Cavalry, cannon, and morale rules, as well as scouts and period weapons are all included. The game is published as a booklet of rules only, so players must supply their own 1/32 scale plastic army men. Civil War Pigs is designed for two or more players, ages ten and up. Got a bag of plastic Civil War army guys and you've got a game!

16504.description: A simple roll and move game. You can roll the dice and move as often as you like. But if you roll a 5 you have to go back to start. If you roll a 6 your turn just ends. Graphics by Doris Matthaeus.
16504.name: Trau Dich

16507.description:
The Golden Medusas is an expansion for the Renegade Legion Interceptor game published by Fasa in 1987.

It describes some of the deadly space battles between the Witches of Defiances fighter wing against the Orca squadron of the TOG's Death Express fighter wing. Included are histories of both fighter wings, with briefing on their personalities, skils and personal backgrounds. There is also a unit history, combat readiness and 15 scenarios for you to play.

The book (80 pages) and adds colour and flavour to Renegade Legion: Interceptor.
16507.name: Renegade Legion: Interceptor – The Golden Medusas

16509.description:
The fire Eagles is an expansion for the Renegade Legion Interceptor game published by Fasa in 1987.

It describes some of the deadly space battles in which the fire eagles have taken part. Included are dossiers on the members of the Fire Eagles, with briefing on their personalities, skils and personal backgrounds. There is also a unit history, combat readiness and 15 scenarios pitting the fire eagles against the commonwealth..

The book adds colour and flavour to Renegade Legion: Interceptor.
16509.name: Renegade Legion: Interceptor – The Fire Eagles

16510.description:
This book is an expansion set for the game Renegade Legion: Interceptor from FASA.

It introduces 19 new TOG fighters, 1 corvette and 3 new TOG weapons systems to the gameplay
16510.name: Renegade Legion: Interceptor – TOG Fighter Briefing

16511.description:
This book is an expansion set for the game Renegade Legion: Interceptor from FASA.

It introduces 19 new Commonwealth fighters, 1 corvette and 3 new Commonwealth weapons systems to the gameplay.
16511.name: Renegade Legion: Interceptor – Renegade Fighter Briefing

16512.name: 4 X 4
16512.description:
4x4 (aka Vier mal Vier) is an abstract 4-in-a-row variant in which 2 players use 16 grooved cubes to erect a wall between them, aiming to be the first one to create a sequence of 4 identical shapes in their own side of a wall, or of all 4 different ones. This row can be horizontally, vertically, or diagonally. The cubical building bricks are all unique, come in 4 colours, and the only placement restriction is that each colour is only allowed once in each level or column. When the last brick is added, the completed wall will be 4x4.

On 2 opposing faces of each cube, a groove has been carved out. There are 4 distinct grooves, and the twist is that these grooves rarely mirror each other on either side of a cube. Therefor the wall face will look completely different to each player. The grooves are paired in such a way that within each group of 4 identically coloured cubes, only one cube has an identical shape on both sides (a different one for each colour). The other combinations are unique for that colour, and each combo occurs only one other time within the entire set.

At the start of the game, the cubes are placed on coloured supply strips which show the 4 'footprints' of all the blocks that exist for each colour. The wall is build on the table surface between the players. Players can only see the top cube of each column and the shape of the groove on their side of the wall of the cubes below it. Forward planning, memory skills and deduction all come into play to some extent, as players above all need to prevent that the opponent gets the sequence of 4 first. The supply strips serve as gentle reminders of what is out there.

The pro-version introduces the rule that an opponent can force a player to take back the last played cube if it would prevent the wall from completion, and instead insist on the placement of a cube that would result in a wall with the maximum amount of bricks. It also suggest the removal of the reminder strips.

16513.description:
[Not to be confused with the Wargames Club game Chronicle of the Three Kingdoms ]

This is a Japanese area movement wargame set during Romance of The Three kingdoms period of China. This wargame uses cards to supplement its area movement system.

Very rare even in Japan.

This game is re-development of Seikiheikuu.
16513.name: Chronicles of the Three Kingdoms

16514.name: Scooby-doo! Monster Chase
16514.description: This card game combines a Scooby-Doo theme with Blackjack-like mechanics. Players are trying to capture monsters. There are 12 Monster Cards (with high numbers) depicting various creatures from the TV show, and 40 Number Cards (with low numbers) depicting Fred, Daphne, Velma, Shaggy and Scooby. To start, a Monster Card is drawn and placed in the center of the table. On your turn you may either draw 1 Number Card from the pile or pass. You are trying to draw cards whose total is closest to the number on the Monster Card without going over. When all players have passed, the cards are revealed. The player who is closest collects the monster and draws first in the next round. The player who captures the most monsters wins.

16515.description:
"The object of all three games [Beginner's, Advanced, and Memory] is to match two puzzle pieces -- opposites -- and fit them together to make a pair. Need help? Each puzzle piece is specially cut so it only fits one piece -- the opposite that matches it. That's why we call this a self-correcting game. You don't need a grown-up to tell you if it's right. If the pieces don't fit, you know you need to try again!"

Based on the book by Virginia Lee Burton.
16515.name: Mike Mulligan and His Steam Shovel Opposites Game

16516.name: Operation Dovecoat
16516.description: The game comes with two 11x17" map, 280 counters, rules. The map scale is about 1.5 miles per hex. Each combat unit is one platoon to battalion. Turns are 8 hrs. The game simulates the opening few days of the dramatic Egyptian assault across the Suez Canal in October, 1973. The game includes an air game system, a ground system and unique rules where command and control are critical for movement purposes. Use of SAM missiles and SAGGER AT play important roles to keep the Israeli at bay. At first, it appears as a "David vs Goliath" battle because of the disparity of forces. The Egyptian needs to create breaches and bridging and move quickly before the balance favors the Israeli. Time is not a friend to either side at various times in the game.

16517.description:
This game contains 48 cards (12 4-card sets) with pictures of the Berenstain Bears playing various sports like baseball, ice skating and golf. Three games may be played...

The Winning Team: Four cards are dealt to each player and face-up on the table. On your turn, if you can match a card from your hand to a card on the table, you take both cards and place them face-up in a pile in front of you. If you can match a card to the top card on an opponent's pile, you may take the player's entire pile of cards. When no more plays can be made, the player with the most cards wins.

Sport Snap: The deck is dealt out evenly among the players. All players simultaneously turn over their top card. If no cards match, turn over another card. If two or more cards match, the first player to call out a correct matching sport wins all stacks with that card on top. If you make a wrong call, you must give 1 card to each opponent. The player that wins all the cards wins the game.

Spoons: Spoons are placed in the center of the table (one less than the number of players). Each player gets 4 cards. The dealer draws a card and either keeps it or passes it to the next player who also can either keep it or pass it etc. As soon as you have a complete set of 4 cards, take a spoon. All players then grab for the remaining spoons. The player who doesn't get one receives a letter - first an "S", followed by a "P", "O", "O", and finally an "N". When one player has spelled out SPOON the game ends and the player with the least number of letters wins.
16517.name: The Berenstain Bears: Join the Team

16518.name: Orbit
16518.description: The object of this track game is to be the first player to move each of his or her 6 space ships from Earth to another planet. On your turn you spin the spinner and advance a ship the number of spaces indicated. When you reach a planet, you must "orbit" it by following the track arrows around it. If you land on a space marked with a red triangle, you may leave orbit and head for another planet through the connecting path. If you stop on a space with a ship pictured, you may land on the planet. If you land on an opponent's ship, you send that ship back to earth. The first player to land all 6 of his or her ships on 6 different planets is the winner.

boardgamehonor: 2005 Deutscher Lernspielpreis "9 years and up" Nominee
16519.name: Energie 21
16519.description:
The goal of Energie 21 - Mit Energie in die Zukunft (Energy 21 - With Energy into the Future) is to produce as much energy as possible from renewable resources. Each player starts with a county that produces energy from coal, oil and nuclear plants including complete with factories, office buildings, residential areas and stores. All of these consume energy that has to be supplied. In the game it is not only important to plan and build carefully, but also work together with other players to realize large projects more effective through cooperation. Players can trade and haggle with power plants, victory points or leftover energy, but beware of the environmental assessment.
The game was designed for a German government agency to raise awareness of renewable energy planning on a communal level.

16520.name: Dragon's Lair
16520.description:
Based on the ground-breaking (at the time) Laserdisc-based videogame.

Race through the castle and rescue Princess Daphne.

Along with the standard die and cards to randomize the game, the board is also designed to shift. One layer is stationary, the other is mobile.

16521.name: MASH Game
16521.description: Race to obtain the Jeep and/or the Helicopter, then rush to the Finish space under the Tent to receive their transfer orders. The first player to reach the Tent with the Jeep or Helicopter (or both) gets a transfer home and wins the game.

16522.name: Battle of the Planets
16522.description:
Be the first player to capture three monsters, then return to Earth.

The game characters and artwork are based on the Battle of the Planets (Gatchaman) cartoon series from the same time period.

In the television market where I lived as a child (Western Massachusetts, Northern Connecticut, USA), this show was known as G-Force (a re-worked series, which put back the missing content from Gatchaman, but included a dreadful back-beat in every scene).

16523.description:
Description from MNG-AJM Games and Collectibles
Oct 2005 Catalog

TV and film related, licensed by King Features, who made the Popeye cartoons and the old serials that always ended at a crisis point. A game set on the Moons of Mongo. Each player takes the part of Flash, Dale, Zarkov or Emperor Ming. The board shows orbits around each of 6 moons and the players try to be the first to land spaceships on any four of these. Movement is by dice roll, but you can choose which of your 4 ships to move. Landing on an opponent's ship causes it to have to restart. Orbits intersect giving quite a bit of choice of where to move.

Move your three pieces into position on the moons of Mongo. The first player to occupy three moons wins.

From Waddington ad dated 1976: "Flash Gordon Space Adventure Game - Your mission in this thrills-a-second game is to gain control of the moons of Mongo! Who will win? Flash Gordon? Dr Zarkov? Dale Arden? Or Ming the Merciless? Hours of excitement has been packed into this space thriller!!
16523.name: Flash Gordon

16524.name: Grease
16524.description: Compete at placing bids on various records, with each player each using a deck of pre-set bids. The player with the records having the greatest point value at the end is the winner.

16525.description: Players attempt to make six jumps in order to gather the most Combat Jump Cards. While the game uses a spinner instead of a die, the mechanism is purely "roll-and-move".
16525.name: G.I. Joe Marine Paratroop Game

16526.name: I Spy
16526.description: Players attempt to establish control of five consecutive Installation spaces on a Master Intelligence Chart. These consecutive spaces may be horizontal, vertical, or diagonal. The ability to place Assistant Discs, however, is driven both by movement on the main board area and by successful dueling on the special Dueling Mechanism randomizer.

16527.name: Ali Baba and the Forty Thieves
16527.description: Players compete at completing the adventures of Ali Baba. Players must collect a Prize from each of the Adventure areas. Each prize symbolizes one of Ali Baba's adventures in the actual tale. The first player to land by exact count on the Finish space with all four Prizes is the winner and is awarded the "Wedding of Ali Baba and Morgianna" token.

16528.name: Leave It To Beaver Money Maker Game
boardgamefamily: TV Series: Leave it To Beaver
16528.description: Race across the board trying to earn money along the way. Players earn money by drawing cards that can give them a profit or a loss, as well as landing on fixed value spaces. The player to reach the "home" space with the most money wins.

16530.name: The Apprentice Game
boardgameversion: Parker Brothers US Donald Trump First Edition
16530.description: This card-driven game based on the TV show "The Apprentice" features an electronic "boardroom" that tells players, "You're Fired!" Players compete at completing tasks assigned to them by Trump.

16531.name: Escapades
16531.description: This "game" actually consists of a box full of 300 activities, divided up into low, semi, and high action levels. The low action level activities may be questions, creative activities, or team-building exercises, while the high action level activities may consist of races or other athletic or dexterity games suitable for pre-adolescent parties.

16532.name: Girls' Nite Out: The Party Game for Women
16532.description:
From the manufacturer:

Girls Night Out: The Party Game for Women is perfect for when the gals get together. This Sassi Games product is a hilarious game of conversation that gets all of those long-forgotten stories out. The game includes appetizer recipes, 10 funky cocktail recipes (for a charades game), scenario cards that prompt you to tell a story, score sheets, and hot pink pencils!!

16533.name: Ætherverse
16533.description:
From the publisher - ÆTHERVERSE: The Infinite Game of Miniature Battles Now available from Triskele Game Design Studios, Ætherverse is a science-fantasy miniature wargame with infinite possibilities. It's set in a sci-fi universe where the theory of multiple universes was proven to be true... and proving it set off wars across the Ætherverse by opening up new avenues of conquest. This backdrop provides limitless freedom to create worlds and armies, and to fight out wars between universes on your tabletop.

Ætherverse includes background material on over a dozen of these universes and the dominant empires on the Earth in each. The core rulebook includes 17 army lists, featuring the armies of these nations and races. Fifteen battle scenarios are also included to give you reasons to fight.

One of the key features of Ætherverse is the Army Creation System. Designed to allow the player to field any army they can possibly imagine, the Army Creation System presents a set of rules for creating an army from complete scratch. Design an army list to feature any miniatures in your collection and to play battles from anywhere within your imagination. Ætherverse gives you this freedom. There is no limit on what you can create

16534.name: Grolsch Master Game
16534.description:
From the back of the box:

Who is the film buff and who knows most about beer? Who is the sports freak of the party and who is Mr(s). Know-it-all? Maybe there's a talented sketch-artist or actor in the room. If you are blessed with all these talents, or you are just plain lucky, you stand a high chance to become 'Master of the Game'.

Play the Grolsch Master Game and test yourself. Play, roll the dice and become 'Master of the Game'.

Aim of the Game:
Try to reach the finish first with your swing-top bottle, pay the bill and win the game.

Gameplay synopsis With your swing-top bottle you travel from start to finish. Along the way you need to answer various questions or fulfill assignments. But watch out! Every ring brings you closer to the finish, but the questions and assignments become more difficult too. You go from one ring to the next via the doorman ar an open door. But... you don't reach the finish that easily. First you will need to make sure that you have paid your bill. With the beer voucher you won, you can pay the innkeeper. You win these vouchers by correctly answering the questions or fulfilling the assignments.

The Grolsch Master game is a promotional game from the Dutch brewery Grolsch, world famous (in the Netherlands) for it's swing-top bottles. The game is a party game that combines aspects of Trivial Pursuit, Pictionary, Charades etc.

The Trivia questions are divided into the categories Film, Beer, Sports and Various, each category containing 50 cards of 4 questions with increasing difficulty. The question you are asked depends on the ring you are in, the closer to the center, the more difficult the question should be. There are also 150 'the Pub' cards with 4 assignments that require you to draw, impersonate, act out or imitate persons, animals situations or even your thoughts on a particular matter (that you have written down beforehand). A sixth set of cards (30 brewery cards) are comparable to the 'Chance' cards of Monopoly.

You roll the die to determine the number of steps you have to take (you can decide whether you travel clockwise or counter clockwise), and depending on the square you land upon, you need to answer a question or carry out an assignment, you can get to the next ring or you get to draw a 'Brewery' (Chance) card. If you answer a question correctly, you get a beer voucher, otherwise you have to pay a beer voucher. If one of the other players guesses your assignment correctly, both get a beer voucher.

There a two possibilities to get to the next ring: via an open door, or via a doorman. The doorman requires payment in the form of beer vouchers. When you reach the final ring, you need to have enough beer vouchers to pay your bill. The first player reaching the inner circle wins the game.

16536.description:
This picture matching game, with a Winnie the Pooh theme, is actually two games-in-one...
Pooh's Birthday Party: In this game players try to gather up Pooh's friends for the party. On your turn you spin the spinner, place your finger on the same color Dialer hole indicated, and turn the Dial until your finger falls through the hole by Kanga & Roo. If the pointer points to Piglet, Eeyore, Tigger or Kanga and Roo, you may collect the piece of your chosen color that matches that character (if you haven't already). If it points to Pooh, you may collect the Pooh pawn. Be the first to collect the Pooh Pawn and four character pieces of your color to win. The winner gets to assemble all the character pieces to form the gameboard for Game 2.
The Path to Tigger's House: In this game players once again spin the spinner and rotate the color dial, but this time they look at the gift that the character is holding. They then move the Pooh pawn along the gameboard path to the next space with the matching gift picture. The winner is the player that moves the pawn to the last honey pot space by Tigger's house.
16536.name: Party for Pooh!

16537.description: This is Japanese edition of Jim Hind's Aces High/Blue Max combined. Very beautiful map, photographing a miniature terrain. Also includes nice units for nearly every model of aircraft (not generic).
16537.name: The Blue Max

16538.name: The Battle of Five Armies
16538.description:
This is a self contained miniatures battle game based on the Battle of the Five Armies in J.R.R Tolkien's book "The Hobbit". It uses 10mm miniature figure blocks for each of the forces present. The game system is based on Warmaster also by Games Workshop.

The game comes with all the unpainted plastic miniatures and terrain, an unpainted plastic modular hill and a colour printed cardstock river, needed to play the game. The miniatures can be clipped together to be able to play the game relatively quickly, or they can be glued together and painted by those who want a more satisfying visual miniatures game.

The main scenario of the game is the Battle of Five Armies, but rules are included to allow design of your own scenarios. The game was expanded by metal miniatures sold separately in blister packs, but these are no longer available. The rules to include these are included in the game box.

16539.description: Each player makes a list of all the hidden words which can be made from the letters in the wheel linked by straight lines. When time is up the lists are compared. Words which appear on only one list are scored. The longer the word, the greater the score.
boardgameversion: Ravensburger German Edition large box with sand timer
16539.name: Word Wheel

16541.description: The game of Gung Ho is played on an 11 x 11 grid of points. The playing pieces are plastic "towers" that are inserted into the grid points. The idea of the game is to line up a fixed number of towers into a row either diagonally/vertically/or horizontally (5 for 2 players, or 4 for 3-4 players). The game is quite simple, players take turns placing a tower piece into a game board location (once placed it cannot be moved). The first player to meet the victory condition is the winner.
16541.name: Gung Ho

16542.name: Checards
16542.description: The game of Checards is played on essentially a checker board but with cardboard tiles representing playing cards. One player takes the black suits and one the red suits. Once the cards are divided, they are mixed face down and placed onto the playing board so that neither player knows the value of any of the cards until they are placed face up one at a time on the board. Play proceeds by each player in turn moving a card piece forward in a diagonally direction one space. The idea is to eliminate all the opponents cards (cards are eliminated by "jumping" them, but a card is only eliminated if the jumping card is of higher or equal value than the card being jumped)

16543.description: Place chips on the gameboard. Try to have the most chips on the valuable parts of the board. After 7 rounds all chips are placed. Now every player gets points for the placed chips. Player with most points wins.
16543.name: Business

16544.name: Jack Sprat
16544.description: National Games Inc #5014. Children's Nursery Rhyme game from the 1950's. Players take turns rolling the dice then moving their pawn on the illustrated playing board following the instructions on the spaces that contain a rhyme.

16546.name: Save Your Planet
16546.description:
From the box:

You are a special United Nations diplomat representing one of the five continents. Out of the blue, a planetary hazard looms and only swift strategic action will avert it. There are two races against time. First you must use your cunning and tactical diplomacy to outwit your opponents. In the meantime, however, the U.N. Special Envoy is following their course to save the world!

You must fly across the world in your specially commandeered aircraft, collecting and using solutions. You may have to cooperate with other diplomats, who may also have their own hidden agendas.

Meanwhile, the U.N. Special Envoy moves towards their destination and it is out of your control. Use your powers wisely.

16547.name: Climb the Needle
16547.description: Climb the Needle is "the space age game of the Seattle World's Fair 1962". The gameboard is a graphic of the Seattle Space Needle. Gameplay involves rolling 2 d6, moving the player pawn the lower of the two die rolls. Rolling doubles allows the player to make an additional roll and landing on another player's space requires the player occupying the space to move back 5 spaces.

16548.name: The Mission
16548.description: The Mission is an exciting new Christian collectible card game based on modern Christian life with all its challenges and rewards. Players take part in The Mission of life as they reach out to the lost, pursue their relationship with God and guard themselves against the works of the enemy.

16549.name: Peanut Panic
16549.description: This game is different from the 1980 title of the same name. In this game, players are trying to move their 2 peanuts through the peanut butter factory while avoiding the Patrol Truck. On your turn you spin the spinner and check the result. If you spin a color, you advance one of your peanuts along the path to the next space of that color. If you spin "Hop to Front!", you move either of your peanuts in front of the leading peanut. If you spin "ON", you start the Peanut Patrol. This is an electronic truck that drives around a track, scoops up peanuts within its reach and dumps back into the START barrel. The first player to get both of his or her peanuts through the peanut butter factory and onto the FINISH space wins.

16550.description: This game features an electronic merry-go-round on a plastic faux iceberg. Two slides (one for each player) are aimed at its sides. Each player starts with 3 penguins. At the count of three, each player releases a penguin at the top of their slide where they wattle down and (hopefully) land in a merry-go-round slot, like a ball in a roulette wheel. If your timing is off, or if the slot is already occupied, you penguin will drain down a side-chute and back to your launch area. The first player to land all of his or her penguins safely onto the merry-go-round wins.
16550.name: Penguin Shuffle

16551.name: Judah the Christian Soldier Game
16551.description:
Judah the Christian Soldier Game's object is to complete the picture of Judah the Christian Soldier by placing armor cards in the correct location on the game board.
This is done by obtaining game pieces by flicking the spinner, and if it lands on a piece of the armor that you do not have, you get it.

The game is simple and easy to learn. The premise of the game is to help teach children about the spiritual armor of God that is referred to in the book of Ephesians 6:10-18 in the Bible.

16553.name: The Book Game for Kids
16553.description:
The Book Game for Kids is a game based on The Book and The Book for Children paraphrasing the Bible.

The game itself starts by players picking what level of questions that they want to answer; Easy, Medium, or Hard.

The players have pawns that they move around the board from a Start point to a Finish line. First player to cross the Finish line is the winner. Along the way there are ladders and ropes, chutes, action arrows, and different square spaces that all have the players take certain actions.

The rules are able to be modified for younger players. Older children will find the hard level questions on the Question cards to be a challenge though. A good knowledge of the Bible, or Bible stories is a large plus for this game. Scripture references are given on the cards too.

There are also Action cards that will give the player either rewards to help them along or setbacks that will hinder the journey along the board.

The books the game is based around (The Book and The Book for Children) aren't translated version of the Bible, but are easier to read the paraphrasing of the translations to help make the passages and stories easier to understand.

16555.name: U.S.A. Trivia
16555.description: U.S.A. Trivia is a straight-up trivia game featuring United States geography, history and government. Players move on a path looping through the 50 states, beginning in Maine and ending in Hawaii. The color of the state the pawn is resting on determines the color used on the card. Successful answers allow a die roll and another turn, unsuccessful answers pass control.

16556.name: Penny Candy
16556.description: This is a simple matching game with a candy store theme. To begin, the 36 candy cards (gumdrops, candy corn, lollipops etc.) are randomly inserted into slots on the board. On your turn you spin the spinner and get either a result of "1 cent" or "2 cents". If you spin a 1, you pull 1 card from a slot. If you don't have a card in front of you, place it face up in front of you. If you do have a candy card in front of you, but this card doesn't match it, put it back (and remember what it is for later). If you do have a candy card in front of you and this card matches it, set both cards aside and draw again. A spin of 2 allows you to draw 2 cards on your turn. The player with the most matches when all the candy cards have been drawn from the board wins.

16557.name: Peter Pan Game
16557.description: This children's track game is based on the Disney movie. To begin, puzzle pieces are placed face down in the center of Never Land, cards are placed on the Pirate ship, and players choose a pawn with a picture of a character from the film. On your turn you roll the die and advance your pawn around the Never Land path the number of spaces indicated. If you land on a Peter Pan space, you draw a card from the Pirate ship and follow the directions. If you land on a space with a picture of the character on your pawn, you draw a puzzle piece from the center of the board. If the color outline on the piece matches the color of your pawn, you keep it. When you have collected all 5 of your puzzle pieces you may move onto the boat track and head for HOME. The first player to complete his or her puzzle and reach HOME by exact count wins.

16558.name: The Peter Rabbit Game
16558.description: This is a simple track game based on the classic children's story. The gameboard depicts Mr. McGregor's garden. Vegetable chips are mixed and placed near the board (number side down), and the Mr. McGregor pawn is placed on a random garden space. On your turn you turn over a Vegetable chip and advance your Peter Rabbit pawn along the garden path the number of spaces shown on the bottom of the chip. If you land on a "bad" space, you lose your next turn. If you land on the Mr. McGregor pawn, you move backwards to the nearest "bad" space. After you move, you place the Mr. McGregor piece on any "good" space (hoping to block an opponent). Vegetable chips are removed as they are used so it's possible to deduce which move numbers remain. The first player to make it through the garden and reach THE END wins.

16559.description:
This is a wargame set during the German invasion of Poland in 1939. In addition to the historical scenario, it has a number of hypothetical changes that can be made to each side's forces. The game is primarily for two players, but it is possible to play with a third player controlling the Soviet forces.

The game was originally published in 1973, with a revised version published in 1974 and a further revision published in 1976.
16559.name: Poland, 1939: The First Battle

16560.name: Cryptic Mandala
16560.description: This game was created to encourage players to find their own hidden spiritual self and to illuminate our understanding of ourselves in relationship to others and to the universe. The first section of the game involves questions of a Physical, Mental, and Spiritual nature. Further play reveals Insight questions, which elicit unexpected answers, and ultimately challenge each player to overcome self-deception and gain true insight. In answering the questions, players discover personal revelations which facilitate positive change and give rise to new visions for the future.

16561.description: In this children's matching game players race to match all the cards of their color to items on their boards. Each player receives 2 boards depicting a Sesame Street scene with lots of characters and items. The item cards are mixed and placed face down within easy reach of both players. At the count of 3, each player simultaneously turns over a card. If the card's color is the same as the player's boards the player looks for the location of the item, shouts "I found it!" once discovered, and places it in a card space on the board's top. Players return cards that belong to an opponent. The first player to fill all eight card spaces on both of his or her game boards wins.
16561.name: Sesame Street Picture Hunt

16562.description:
From the rulebook:

"Billy Blueberry, Annie Apple, Jerry Cherry, and Peach Melba are having a pie-eating contest, and you're feeding them. You want to be the first player to fill your character's mouth with three pieces of his or her favorite pie!"

The board for this game is built into the box and it uses a cardboard backdrop to depict the 4 pie eaters with their mouths open. Pie pieces (3 of each flavor) are mixed and inserted into box slots to form a pie and hide the flavors. On your turn you draw a pie piece from a slot. If it is the flavor that your character likes, you insert the slice into character's mouth. If it's another player's flavor, you return to the pie. If you draw the Dirty Sock pie piece, you return it and one of your own slices to the pie. The first player to fill their character's mouth with all three of its matching pie pieces wins.
16562.name: Pie Face
boardgamepodcastepisode: Episode 7 - Ding & Dent's Holiday Gift Guide!

16563.name: Pirates of the Caribbean
16563.description: This track game, based on the theme park ride, is part of the Disneyland series of games. On your turn you roll the die and move along the track the number of spaces indicated. You may try to get a Treasure card by moving onto one of the branch tracks leading to a pirate holding a treasure chest. If you roll a number printed on the chest you take a card. Some cards show gold and are needed to win, others show Tiny (the fat lady at the auction) or a pirate in the dungeon and are worthless but are kept so that opponents don't know how many treasures you have. Landing on a peg leg pirate space forces you to lose a treasure. The first player with 2 treasures to reach the end of the boat track by exact count wins.

16564.name: Poor Jenny
16564.description:
A simple game, a little like Snakes and Ladders. Not politically correct now. You race your coloured (and named!) donkey up the game board from 1 to 100. The board portrays a donkey being chased by a stereo-typed Black Maid.

No skill whatever required, progress is purely random. Slightly notable for the dice; there are four, each of which has the name of 2 of the donkeys twice and two of them once, so each donkey name occurs 6 times over the four dice.

16565.description:
Hoppit! Is a Halma variant where each player has 6 toadstools and 5 frogs. Toadstools move like a chess queen, frogs move by hopping over adjacent toadstools of any color.

The objective is to be the first to get all of your frogs to the opposite end of the board.

Contents:
6 toadstools in each of 4 colors
5 frogs in each of 4 colors
13 x 13 board
16565.name: Hoppit!

16566.name: Insider Trading
16566.description:
Insider Trading, which has been dubbed Pacific Northwest Rails II, focuses on the five major lines that served Spokane and surrounding vicinity. It is the first Gandy Dancer game featuring the hauling of commodities.

As in the prior two Gandy Dancer releases, players earn money by making runs with their railroads and by buying and selling shares on the stock market. Players take turns investing in railroads and using those railroads to ship goods in this acquisition race.

Insider Trading has the added features of hauling commodities for additional profits, and as its name indicates, manipulating the stock market by using insider knowledge. But don't get caught up in a scandal or it will cost you dearly.

Players start with a stock portfolio of $100 and some cash (the amount varies depending upon the number of players). In turn, a player may play a movement card, roll a die or pay to move around the gameboard. The space on which a player lands may allow that player to buy and stock in a railroad, use that railroad for shipping, draw and trade commodity cards (sets of which can result in big rewards) and draw insider trading cards (these allow stock manipulation). There are penalty spaces but these can only be landed on because of a die roll.

The game ends when one railroad has hauled one load of each of six commodity groups or when one player goes bankrupt. The player with the most money is the winner.

16567.name: Can You Beat Ken?
16567.description:
From an article on CNN.com:

The idea behind "Can You Beat Ken?" is a match up between Ken [Jennings, Jeopardy! champion] and the players as they try to answer some 1,200 trivia questions broken up into several different categories such as sports, science, contemporary music and history.

The challenge is to see which player, including Ken, is able to reach $2.6 million (the amount Jennings actually won on Jeopardy!) in prize money first.

"The game is unique in that we actually tested Ken with all 1,200 questions," [University Games spokesman Alex] Plant said, although neither he nor Jennings could recall how many of the game's questions Jennings actually answered correctly.

"Ken may have gotten some right and some wrong and we recorded how he answered each question on the card itself," Plant said. That allows players to see how they held up against the Jeopardy! whiz.

16568.name: Pillage
16568.description:
Pillage! A game where you must pillage jewels from neighboring castles and make it back to your own before the other knights do. You can be sent back to your castle without any jewels if you get caught or jousted with and lose.
There are many paths you can take but some could be blocked. The cool thing is that you have 2 knights to control so if one is at a road block or staying back to defend your castle, the other knight can continue the pillaging.
There are 2 dice involved: A specialty one and a regular 6 sided. The closer to 4 players you have, the more interesting it gets with so many knight wandering around.

16569.name: Triton II
16569.description:
Set in an imaginary galaxy, the game pits the Triton Empire against the Megan Confederation. The basis for the conflict revolves around the shortage of a mineral called "galactium" used to power the propulsion systems of starships and vehicles. The Triton empire has invaded the mining planet Abarathascan (renamed Triton II after the invasion by the Tritons) to gain control of the galactium supply. The Megan Confederation will have none of that and hence the invasion of Triton.

The game is played on 3 separate 8-1/2" x 11" hex maps depicting the main mining centers of Triton II. Basic wargame mechanics such as Zones of control, Combat results tables, Terrain Effects Tables, describe the basic gameplay. Both sides use transport ships to move ground units between maps. Production points are alloted at the beginning of gameplay, used by each side to purchase their forces. All space craft movement over the planet surface is conducted in a simultaneous plot mechanism. Bases on the planet surface can be used to repair damaged craft or vehicles. Victory conditions are determined by the scenario and involve accumulating victory points obtained by occupying the planets resource centers.

16570.name: Golferino
16570.description: This game, endorsed by Lucille Ball, is a nine-hole tabletop miniature golf course. The course is molded plastic, complete with trees and water hazards. Some holes have special obstacles such as a tunnel, bridge, and a waterwheel. Everything slopes down to the center where a small golfer stands. He is controlled from the side of the board using a knob to pivot him in the direction you want, and a lever that swings his club. On your turn you place a metal ball in the depression in front of the golfer, aim him at the hole you're playing and shoot the ball. If you miss, the ball will drain down the slope and back into the depression. The player who finishes the course in the fewest strokes wins.

16571.description: This game can be called a variant of Backgammon. On the stones of the players are Gold coins which can be stolen. Goal of the game is to exit the board with as much stones and gold as possible.
16571.name: Sovereign

16572.name: Street Violence
16572.description:
Street Violence is a tabletop miniatures game.
The rulebook is free to download on the publisher website.

16573.name: Murder à la carte: Murder on the Grill
16573.description:
The "Murder Mystery Party" line of murder party games is the most extensive. Part of the Bepuzzled line was originally founded by Lombard Marketing, Inc. University Games acquired Bepuzzled in February 1999.

These games play just like other main-stream murder party games like How to Host a Murder, Evening of Murder, Mysteries by Vincent, or Milton Bradley's Life of the Party.

Somebody put a barbecue fork through car dealer Tom Dooley, and that somebody is at your dinner party

This is a complete 1950's murder mystery that places your guests as the chief suspects. . Six to eight friends play roles with plenty of scripts and suggestions on how to ham it up. The set includes an audiotape guide, background booklets for each player, special clues (including mysterious checks and blackmail letters), and anything else you need for an evening of unpredictable fun. There are even party invitations and tasty recipes

The suspects include:

Bobby Sox

Chubby Cheddar

Johnny Angel

Tiara Diamond

Ivan Spudnick

Barbie Q

16574.description:
This game is based on a German expression which refers to someone who tends to exaggerate when telling a story. Literally, the expression would say "Don't convert a midge (mosquito) into an elephant." This is the aim of this game. Whoever is the first to convert their midges into elephants wins the game.

<!-- Entry audited by (nsolitander) (13-08-2009) --!>
16574.name: Mut zur Mücke

16575.description: This game features characters from the Disney film racing canoes down a river. The board is two river pieces that connect at the ends. If the lead player moves off the front board, the rear board is disconnected and placed in front. On your turn you play as many cards from your hand as you want/can: Canoe Cards move you 1 space, Rock and Log cards are used as hazards to thwart your opponents, Paddle Cards let you escape a hazard. If you land on a Leaf Space you draw a Leaf Token. The first player to collect 3 Leaf Tokens and land on a Shore Space wins.
16575.name: Pocahontas Canoe Race Game

16576.description: This is a simple children's memory game using characters from the Disney film. Thirty character picture tokens are inserted into into leaf tiles that are then placed face down in a 5x6 grid. On your turn you turn over a tile so that all players may see it. If the token revealed is Pocahontas, John Smith or Meeko, you remove and keep the token then replace the tile face down. If the tile reveals a token of any other character, a character you've already collected or is empty, you replace the tile and do nothing. The first player to collect 1 Pocahontas token, 1 John Smith Token and 1 Meeko token wins the game.
16576.name: Pocahontas Picture Hunt

16577.name: Red-Handed
16577.description:
From the Manufacturer:

You can have a "green thumb," turn "blue in the face," or be "tickled pink," but don't get caught Red-Handed. From "blue jeans" to "blackjack," and from "Yellowstone" to the "Red Sea," Red-Handed is the game where every colorful clue gets you a shade closer to a win. Guess the answer on the game card and your opponents will be "green with envy" as you get to pick from the Score Card pile. Pick a Score Card and you're well on your way to a win! But pick a card with a red hand on it, and you've been caught "Red-Handed!" Luckily, you won't have to cut through any "red tape" to get back in the game. Be the first player to collect five (5) Score cards and you're the 'thumbs up' winner! So "roll out the red carpet" and sharpen your "gray matter" - you've just been "given a green light" to play Red-Handed!

16578.name: Mark Breslin's Yuk Yuk's Comedy Game
16578.description:
From the box...

Laughter becomes easy as you compete to play 1 of the 5 Closer cards in your hand against the Opener line on the table. Only after putting your card in the red viewfinder will you find out how the Yuk Yuk's panel of judges scored your card. Use enough of the funny Closer lines and proceed around the board and enter Yuk Yuk's comedy hall of fame.

16579.description: This is another Crusher Joe game from Tsukuda hobbies but this time uses a magic realm type system.
16579.name: Crusher Joe: Roleplay Game in CrusherJoe

16581.name: Alton Metropoly
16581.description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μόνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεῖν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

This is a game like Monopoly, but centers around Alton, IL.

16582.name: Affton Opoly
16582.description: This is a game like Monopoly, but centers around Affton, MO. Includes game board, fate & chamber cards, property cards, play money, green and red discs, 4 tokens and 2 dice, and original instructions.

16583.name: Beat the Traffic Warden
16583.description:
(from the back of the box)
"Give him back that ticket!
Ever since September 1960, when the very first parking ticket was given to an unsuspecting Doctor on call. It has been a global game not to get a ticket.
Now the game has come to life and you can "Give him back that ticket!" Over thirty years later and the game is still being played on the streets. Even if you have never had a parking ticket, Beat the Traffic Warden will appeal to all as a fun, spirited and enjoyable board game. It is not a game of pure chance, you need skill, tactical risk taking and determination to beat the Traffic Warden.
A game that generates great excitement and may bring out the rebel in you! It's a game we can all relate to. Feel really good handing the tickets back to the Traffic Warden, or get a great buzz from playing the Warden and handing out tickets yourself. Whatever side suits your personality. Beat the Traffic Warden makes the impossible possible."

Functionally, this is a straight-forward roll-and-move Monopoly game, but with a player-controlled adversary to add extra interaction to the game. The plastic bits are very nice.

16584.name: Great Lakes Cargo
16584.description: This is a game of shipping on the Great Lakes, involving picking up and delivering loads for profits while avoiding the many dangers of traveling on the Great Lakes.

16586.name: Empire
16586.description:
Buy, sell and trade famous companies as you try to cash in on good advertising or favorable publicity by avoiding pitfalls like anti-trust, recession or taxes. Empire allows constant bargaining with other players and decision making that will have you second guessing yourself most of the time.

The final object of the game is to have the most money when the tax revolt occurs at the end of the game.

16587.name: I Spy Rhyme-A-Thon
16587.description: Based on the "I Spy" series of books, this game offers the players a chance to create their own "I Spy" riddles. Each player is given two word cards and a fill-in-the-blank rhyme card. The players race to complete the rhyme using the two word cards dealt. Other words to complete the rhyme may be found on "I Spy" cards on the board or objects in the room. Players move around the board based on the order in which they finished their rhymes.

16588.name: Pokémon Silph Co.
16588.description: This game is part of the 3-D Expanding Adventure Series of Pokemon games that can be played by themselves or combined with other games in the series. In this game Giovanni is holding the president of Silph Co. hostage and it's up to the players to free him. Using dice for movement, players move through the many levels of Silph Co. in order to battle other players, catch various Pokemon, and get more power. They also search for Warp spaces that will move them to different levels, and the Red Warp that will take them to the space next to Giovanni. The first player to find the right Warp Tile and defeat Giovanni's Pokemon wins.

16589.name: Pokémon Tower
16589.description:
This game is part of the 3-D Expanding Adventure Series of Pokemon games that can be played by themselves or combined with other games in the series. From the rulebook:

Fuji has the Poke Flute you need, but you have to battle your way to the top of the Pokemon Tower to get it! Roll the dice and move through the rooms. Collect cards, battle other players, and catch Pokemon along the way. But beware! Ghost Pokemon may attack you. When you get to the top, you have one last challenge ... be the first player to defeat Team Rocket! If you do--you win!

16590.name: Pokémon S.S. Anne Game
16590.description:
This game is part of the 3-D Expanding Adventure Series of Pokemon games that can be played by themselves or combined with other games in the series. The S.S. Anne is a cardboard boat with multiple decks. From the rulebook:

You need the HM 01 "Cut" from the Captain, but there's just one problem ... Gary, your old rival, is blocking your passage! Roll the dice and make your way around the decks to battle and collect Pokemon. Then, when you get to the Captain's cabin on the top deck, get ready for the ultimate battle. Gary is waiting, and if you're the first player to defeat his Pokemon--you win!

16591.name: Victory By Any Means Source: Wars of the Kuissians and Boltians
boardgameexpansion: Victory By Any Means: Campaign Guide
boardgamefamily: Victory By Any Means Campaign Series
16591.description:
Two warring juggernauts, the Boltian Star League and the Kuissian Empire, have finally reached a peace accord after their first wearisome conflict. Unfortunately, the appearance of the Terran Union in a critical system destroyed this delicate peace in an instant, sparking the Second War which would haunt the participants for years to come.

These are The Wars of the Boltians and Kuissians, the first VBAM source book set in the Boltian and Kuissian Universe. This book covers each empire's humble beginnings and trials as they journey to space. Included for the player is a complete set of histories, ships, and scenarios covering the First and Second Boltians and Kuissian Wars. Everything you need to run a Victory by Any Means campaign is contained within this 108-page source book!

Expands:

Victory By Any Means: Campaign Guide

16592.name: Neighborhood Hike
16592.description:
Objective: To collect five neighborhood place cards depicting places shown on a neighborhood map.

How to play: Each player selects a neighborhood map card and holds it in his or her hand. The remaining map cards are set aside.

The dealer shuffles the neighborhood place cards and deals five cards face-down to each player. The remaining cards in the deck are placed face-down in a pile. The dealer draws the top card and lays it face-up to begin the discard pile.

The first player picks up a card from either the deck or the discard pile. If the card matches an item on his or her neighborhood map card, the player keeps the card and discards an unwanted card. If the card does not match, the player places it face-up on the discard pile.

Players take turns picking up and discarding cards. When all cards have been drawn from the deck, the discard pile is reshuffled to start a new pile.

The first player to collect five of the places displayed on his or her neighborhood map card wins the game!

16593.name: Cosmic Critters:  Consonant Blends
16593.description:
A phonics game! Consonant blends. Help the critters make a word!

"It's a game of making words. Just match the critters to their ships! Play alone or with up to 4 players. Includes 4 game boards, 40 playing cards, and simple directions.

It's easy! It's fun! It builds important phonic skills.

16594.name: Mapping the Town
16594.description: "Mapping the Town is a simple, fun game that introduces the concept of map reading. Understanding the relationships of numbers and letters, logical thinking and attention to detail are skills players will develop during play. One side of the board can be played as a simple lotto game of matching picture cards to identical but smaller pictures on the board. The flip side of the board is also a lotto game that requires matching the grid coordinate on the card to the grid references on the board."

16595.description:
The setting is Okinawa April 1945 and centers on the Kakazu Ridge area, an insignificant looking little hill occupied by the Japanese 13th Independent Battalion (who were willing to die in place fighting for their Emperor). US intelligence had failed to realize just how extensive the enemy was entrenched in this area. There are 7 pre-set cave complexes used in the various scenarios.

ASL Journal #2 contains a lot of ASL material in a magazine format. 'ASL Journal #2 contains 24 ASL scenarios, a full-sized (22"x32") historical map of Kakazu Ridge (Okinawa) two countersheets, and some necessary rulebook pages (Chapter Z rule additions).

Journal #2 Scenarios (scenario J13-J17 use Kakazu Ridge map):
ASL Scenario J13 The Gorge
ASL Scenario J14 On the Hoss' Side
ASL Scenario J15 Turning Off the Spigot
ASL Scenario J16 Kakazu's Tombs
ASL Scenario J17 Clearing Kakazu
ASL Scenario J18 The Pinnacle
ASL Scenario J19 Merzenhausen Zoo
ASL Scenario J20 The Guns of Naro
ASL Scenario J21 Scobie Preserves
ASL Scenario J22 Oh Joy!
ASL Scenario J23 Kampfgruppe at Karachev
ASL Scenario J24 Smashing the 3rd
ASL Scenario J25 The Weigh In
ASL Scenario J26 Round Two
ASL Scenario J27 High Tide at Heiligenbeil
ASL Scenario J28 Inhumaine
ASL Scenario PB6a It's About Time
ASL Scenario J29 The Capture of Balta
ASL Scenario J30 Nocturnal Attrition
ASL Scenario J31 Lovat First Sight
ASL Scenario J32 Panzer Graveyard
ASL Scenario J33 The Slaughterhouse
ASL Scenario J34 Men of the Mountains
ASL Scenario J35 Siam Sambal

(source: MMP website and user's description)
16595.name: ASL Journal #2

16596.name: Jetan
16596.description:
Jetan, or Martian Chess, is a two-player abstract game played on a 10-by-10 board. Each side has a set of twenty pieces of varying types, with each type having its own set of movement options.

The game is unlike traditional Chess in a few important respects:
All pieces in Jetan have limited movement (i.e. the Chief moves three spaces in any direction or combination of directions).
One piece on each side (the Princess) cannot capture other pieces.
The conditions for a win or a draw (described below) are unusual.

"The game is won when a player places any of his pieces on the same square with his opponent's Princess, or when a Chief takes a Chief. It is drawn when a Chief is taken by any opposing piece other than the opposing Chief; or when both sides have been reduced to three pieces, or less, of equal value, and the game is not terminated in the following ten moves..." -- from Edgar Rice Burroughs' novel "The Chessmen of Mars".

16597.name: Fantasy Warriors Companion
16597.description:
Fantasy Warriors Companion is a supplement for the Fantasy Warriors Miniatures Base Game. The supplement includes color counters and covers:

The Undead
Giant Creatures
Battlefield Equipment
Sneaky Tricks
Mercenaries
Dwarven Cannon
Goblin War Giant
Dragons
Paladins
Amazons
Revised Army Lists and more

Expands:

Fantasy Warriors

16598.name: The Time-Life Library of Curious & Unusual Facts
16598.description:
From the Rules page and Category Card:

OBJECT OF THE GAME:

To be the first player to collect all five game tokens (one from each of the four categories plus a "Wild Card") by correctly answering the Time-Life Curious & Unusual Facts trivia questions.

CATEGORY DESCRIPTIONS:


Feats and Wisdom of the Ancients
Mysteries of the Human Body
Forces of Nature
Vanishings


GAME COMPONENTS:

Game board, two dice, 169 trivia question cards with tray (x 4 Categories = 676 Questions in Total), six plastic playing pawns, 30 game tokens (six of each design), one category description card.

16599.description:
Simulates the land battle between Caesar and Pompey during the Roman Civil War, 48 B.C. This is a tactical-level battle game. {Description and information from The Complete Book of Wargames, by the Editors of Consumer Guide, 1980}

480 counters
16599.name: Pharsalus

16600.name: Robert the Bruce
16600.description: This game deals with the Scots Wars of Independence in the thirteenth and fourteenth centuries, on land and sea. The general objective is to be crowned King of the Scots. There are five basic scenarios. {Description and information from The Complete Book of Wargames, by the Editors of Consumer Guide, 1980}

16601.description:
This is one of Tsukuda Hobby's SF Series games, #9 in that series (the game is numbered HG-009-4000). It bears the subtitle "The Game of Space War in Star Trek" in addition to the less generic "Invasion of Klingon Empire."

This is definitely a strategic game, given the 4-part mounted map showing the United Federation of Planets, the Klingon Empire (or a portion thereof), the Romulan Empire (ditto), and a large amount of space between these. Production is clearly important, as there seem to be many rules sections covering factories.

The game definitely appears to have two sides, the Federation and the Klingons. It gives the appearance of allowing either 2 or 4 players - the map has a line down the middle which would split it reasonably enough for this purpose. Presumably two players split the Federation and the other side has a Klingon and a Romulan player.

The missions of the USS Enterprise are clearly of some importance to the game. The green lines on the map appear to chart these (many of the systems have names familiar from the original TV series), there is a rules section labeled "ST Game Enterprise Mission Chart," and one of the scenarios is called "Missions of Enterplize" (I swear!). Other missions include "la Brandy de Camus" and a campaign game.
16601.name: Star Trek: The Invasion of Klingon Empire

16603.description:
Indian Ocean Adventure, designed by Marc Miller and released in 1978 by Game Designers Workshop, simulates the Japanese raid on the British bases in Ceylon in early 1942 and uses the same basic concepts and rules used by the designer in his previous games, Coral Sea and Battle for Midway. It includes special design features to simulate the fluidity of modern naval actions dominated by aircraft rather than surface gunfire, including turn segments decided by an initiative factor and local weather variations, so common in the Pacific and Indian Oceans. Each counter represents a single capital ship or about 8 aircraft. Complex features such as aircraft maintenance and efficiency of land airfields are represented in the game rules.

This is an unusual subject. There certainly aren't many games that contain Fulmars, Albacores and Walrus in the counter mix.

The game includes:
240 counters, printed on one side only
A 22" x 28" mapsheets
A Rule Book
Player aids and charts
A pad of combination Ship Status and Location Chart sheets
16603.name: Indian Ocean Adventure

16604.name: One Tub Bilge
16604.description:
A parody game intended as a lampoon of (or pot-shot at) Steve Jackson Games by Howard Thompson. The U.S. ship tries to sink the "Commies." Published in Interplay number 2, Metagaming's house organ.

The name is based on the Steve Jackson game One-Page Bulge

16605.name: The Way of the Warrior
16605.description:
The Way of the Warrior is a highly abstract game of conflict in medieval Japan. Players take the part of opposing daimyos and attempt to either capture the other player's daimyo or assault the other player's stronghold and rescue the hostage they are holding.

Each player has an identical set of 16 cardboard pieces representing his daimyo, a ronin, a ninja, archers, etc. Each type of piece has different abilities - they have different ranges, some can attack more than once on a turn, some can jump other pieces, etc. On each turn a player draws a card and then rolls either one die (if a Karma, or event card was drawn) or two dice (otherwise) and can that many spaces in total, using any number of pieces.

In addition to the Karma cards there are Warrior cards. Some of these can be used for special effects and others can be collected in sets to deploy the more powerful units on board, among other uses.

16606.name: Spinette
boardgameversion: Cream boxtop backgound with stylized top edition
16606.description: This early Milton Bradley game used a top which you spin in order to try and score points into different holes on the playing board.

16607.name: El Paso
16607.description:
Each player begins with 5 cards from a standard 52 card deck plus 2 jokers. Draw a card, keep it or pass it to the player on your left. If you pass it, you must draw and keep the next card. You may then discard pairs of cards, with some discards having special powers (e.g. force other players to draw cards). The round ends if any player discards all their cards or the deck runs out. Score penalty points for cards remaining in hand. The player with the fewest points at the end of five rounds wins.

El Paso was designed as a version of Give Me The Brain to be played with a standard card deck, and was first published by Dalmuti's Restaurant in 1998.

16608.name: Jewels in the Attic
16608.description:
A kingdom of glittering jewels awaits any group of adventurers who prove their craftiness to the Jewelkeeper. Fun seekers work together to decode the Jewelkeeper's tricks and traps that protect his treasure.

Your house is the gameboard! - a drafty, creaking mansion full of sneaky elves, mischievous furniture and laughing winds.
Your mission: be clever and lucky and make your way through the mysterious rooms of this dusty old mansion - the library, guest room, and dark cellar. You will find yellow clue discs in each room, which give you rewards, activities or even trap you. You can complete challenges using your blue disc tool cards. You face your most difficult, final challenge when you reach the attic...choose wisely and capture your sparkling reward!

16609.name: Scaventure
16609.description: Scaventure instantly injects spontaneity and fun into any dinner party, corporate ice-breaker or weekend get-together. Anything can happen - from discovering what the soup of the day is at the local diner or dressing a male team member in drag to acquiring an undertaker's business card or acting out a scene from a classic movie. Ages 16 and up.

16610.name: Scaventure Kids
16610.description:
Scaventure Kids asks kids Ages 6 - 12 to locate items around the house or yard or even create, perform or draw new things themselves. Whether it's demonstrating a pet trick, making a sandwich a gorilla would like or learning to hula dance.

Editorial Review from Amazon.com:
"A scavenger hunt in a can, Scaventure Kids provides everything needed to plan and execute a challenging hunt. Included in the cardboard container are 150 cards, instructions, and team stickers. The cards each have four items for a team to find or do. Cards ask players to do things like "Find two bags with different store names" or "Have your team act out a scene from your favorite movie." Each team takes out cards and has 30 minutes to carry out the tasks. At the rendezvous, the teams share their finds and winners are chosen. For rainy days, vacations, or parties, Scaventure Kids is a simple and creative activity that fosters teamwork and creative problem-solving. --Lee Strucker"

16611.name: Telly Addicts
16611.description:
Board game version of Noel Edmond's UK Trivia TV series "Telly Addicts."

Answer questions on specialist subject by moving around your chosen department - Soaps & Sagas, Top of the Pops, Guess Who, Comedy, Children's TV, Comedy, News or Sci-Fi.

Be the first player to get each of "your star tokens" back to the remote control. Only then can you take the Star Challenge and become champion Telly Addict.

16612.name: Viersprong
16612.description: Insert the disks into the hidden channels of the game board in Double Cross. With correct planning — and not too much interference from other players — they'll come out the other end! Eject five of your discs from the board first, and you win. Just watch out for the green ones...

16613.name: A Question of Pop
16613.description:
A Question of Pop is the board game of the highly successful UK BBC television series hosted by Jamie Theakston.

Promises to keep your family and friends entertained for hours as they remember everything from the music they listened to many years ago through to more modern music featuring rounds such as A Side/B Side and Name the Year.

The mechanics include dice based movement and time limited question answering using an egg timer.

16614.description:
"A Question of Sport" is the trivia board game version of the amazingly popular UK BBC television series of the same name.

The original version of the game, featuring the TV game show hosts Bill Beaumont, David Coleman and the late lamented Emlyn Hughes on the box cover was released in 1986 and included 1200 question and answer cards, 2 scoreboards, 2 picture boards, 2 dice and 2 shakers.

It remains ever popular and has been re-released many times and in several formats since including junior and sports themed expansion versions. Later versions of the game also included a "Mystery Guest Video Cassette."
16614.name: A Question of Sport
boardgameexpansion: A Question of Sport: Booster Pack Team 1
A Question of Sport: Booster Pack Team 2
A Question of Sport: Famous Sporting Faces
boardgamefamily: TV Series: A Question of Sport

16615.name: Questillo
16615.description:
Questillo is a game of crossword building - each player has a grid on a sheet of paper, and adds words to it to make a crossword type layout.

The words added are based on clues, which come from cards drawn from a box. So a clue might say 'A great game', and each player has to get the name of a great game added to their existing set of words on their grid.

Think of a cross between 'Pictionary' and 'Scrabble', and you're nearly there...

Points are achieved for words accepted by everybody, and can be doubled or tripled on certain bonus squares. Most points wins!

16616.name: The Battle of Brandywine
16616.description:
A less complex wargame covering the battle along Brandywine Creek near Philadelphia, PA in 1777. George Washington squares off against the British General Sir William Howe.
144 counters

16617.description:
(from the rules:)

The Wilderness Campaign is an historical simulation of the conflict between Robert E. Lee's Confederate Army of Northern Virginia and Ulysses S. Grant's Union Army of the Potomac, from May 3 through July 1, 1864.

There are two historical scenarios that may be utilized. The initial stage of the actual campaign is portrayed in the May scenario, from the battle at the Wilderness to the battle at Cold Harbor. The June scenario portrays the campaign from Cold Harbor to the siege of Petersburg. Several optional scenarios permit the "what if?" possibilities of the campaign to be simulated.

(from the Designer's Notes:)

In a real sense neither side won the campaign since so little of either side's objectives was accomplished. But, strategically, Grant really won by allowing all the other Union commanders to successfully advance. He did it by pinning the Army of Northern Virginia every step back to Richmond and bleeding the South so dry that no assistance was possible. The cost was high (and many think higher than necessary), but it worked.


Contents:


22" x 28" mapsheet
255 counters
1 rules folder (10 pages)
1 terrain effects chart
2 combat result/scenario sheets
1 6-sided die


(originally published in the white box/tray format)


Uses a system similar to SPI's Lee Moves North.
16617.name: The Wilderness Campaign: Lee vs. Grant, 1864

16618.name: Centipede: A Cardcade Game
16618.description: This is a card game for Ages 5 and up based on the famous Atari Centipede video game. The game consists of 56 cards that differ in (1) background color, (2) insect, and (3) number. Players play cards as quickly as they can. Each card played must match the top card on one of the two play piles on one of the three variables. The first person to play all his or her cards earns a centipede section. The first person to win three pieces wins the game.

16619.name: War Stories
16619.description:
War Stories is the first game by Symbiose, a small Dutch publisher. Only 1000 copies were printed.

It is a small strategic boardgame for two players that can be best described as a combination of Chess and Memory with a 16th century feudal Japan theme added to the mix.
The story is that two Daimyos are discussing a battle they once fought, during a tea ceremony (the discussion, not the battle). The problem is that both Daimyos don't have very good memories. They try to remember how the battle developed and who won eventually.

As mentioned, the basic mechanics of the game are a combination of Chess and Memory. Finding combinations of identical cards on the board results in new units, which act as chess pieces. Hence, good memory and some tactical insight may be of good use in playing this game.

16620.name: Domination
16620.description:
From the publisher's press release (the game is scheduled to be introduced at The American International Toy Fair in New York City, February 17-23, 2005, and should be in stores by June 2005.

You’ve never played Dominoes like this before ... it’s strategic, challenging and suspenseful, while at the same time, classic in its simplicity. Play dominoes on their corresponding spaces on the game board. As you complete squares, you conquer territories and claim them as your own. Dominate the game board and you win! For ages 8 and up.

From a review in "Games Quarterly", Winter 2005:

The Domination board is a seven-by-seven grid of squares with sets of numbers that resemble half a domino at each corner. Each player starts with seven dominoes. When it's your turn, you lay down a domino along one edge of a square so that the numbers on both corners match your domino. Then you draw another domino.

If your play closes off the fourth side of a square, you put a poker chip in the center of that square to claim it. You keep playing until all the dominoes are used, which fills up the entire board. At that point, the player with the most chips on the board wins the game.

16621.description:
Jandar's Oath is the third Small Expansion Set (wave 3) in the HeroScape series.

There are 4 booster packs:

Kilts & Commandos
Gorillas & Hounds
Monks & Guards
Heroes of Nostralund




Each pack contains 4-7 new figures, army unit cards and some terrain pieces, but no glyphs.
16621.name: Heroscape Expansion Set: Jandar's Oath
boardgameexpansion: Heroscape Master Set: Rise of the Valkyrie
Heroscape Master Set: Swarm of the Marro

16624.description: Simulation of the Japanese campaign to capture the peninsula of Bataan with 5 optional scenarios.
16624.name: The Battle for the Philippines: Bataan

16625.name: Bio One
16625.description:
"Rules for exact hit location and damage determination; for use with gunpowder period man-to-man rules." 12 page booklet.

"Bio One was created in 1974 to incorporate a degree of realism into a field of wargaming which was sorely lacking. Bio One provides a complete and accurate system of damage location and effects for any gunpowder period of warfare. Bio One will prove an interesting addition to any set of man-to-man rules which uses gun fire . . . Bio One can be thought of as a flow-chart, each event follows a definite sequence, starting with a bullet being fired and ending with a wound of a certain degree of seriousness. This is determined by a combination of probability and chance."

16626.name: Evangelion CCG
16626.description: The Carddass Masters G Neon Genesis Evangelion Card Game is a trading card game set in the world of the Japanese animation Neon Genesis Evangelion. Each player, using the cards he has on hand, tried to achieve the Consummation of one of the main characters in the Evangelion universe: Shinji, Rei, Asuka, Misato, Ritsuko, or Gendou. Although the game is playable with two players, three to five players is best.

16627.name: The Royle Family
16627.description:
Based on the UK Television Series of the same name following the exploits of the Manchester couch potato Royle family.

The object of the game is to answer trivia questions in order to collect Club biscuits. You miss turns if "Dave buys you a pint in The Feathers" or if "Barbara puts the kettle on for a brew......."

The mechanics are simple dice based movement with card drawing. Three decks of cards are used: Television Facts, Chance cards and the endearingly titled "My Arse" deck which takes it's name from Jim Royle's favourite saying.

Believe it or not there is a special edition which comes with a novelty toilet seat cover with a picture of Jim Royle on it!

16628.name: The Royles "My Arse" Game
16628.description:
"My Arse" is a Cheatwell Games trivia game based on Granada Television Ltd's "Royle Family" situation comedy show.

Its a variation of the card based trivia theme in which players pit their wits against Jim, the Royle Family's fountain of all knowledge and have to decide if "facts" on the trivia cards are "Sound" (true) or "My Arse" (false.)

Here's how the marketing material describes it:

A classic game of truth or bluff, you have to choose the facts from the guff...decide whether Jim really knows his onions or is simply full of hot air.

Do you agree with Jim and head for a pint at the Feathers or grumble your way to the kitchen to brew another cuppa?

Of one thing you can be certain...you're in for a right Royle battle in this off-beat trivia board game.

16629.name: Ript
16629.description:
A deck of cards marked with special functions as well as standard card values. The game is played during a round of disc golf. Each player receives three cards at the beginning of the game and one for winning a hole. They may play their card to perform the action stated on it, such as taking a mulligan, subtracting one stroke from their score, trading a disc with another player, swapping 'lies' with another player, or forcing another play to throw with their off hand. An official variant involves collecting the best poker hand by the end of the game.

Home Page: http://www.knagames.com/Ript%20Community/Community.htm

16630.name: Dr. Futsch
16630.description:
Dr. Futsch is Alex Randolph's version of Sleuth, a simple deduction cardgame. The goal of the game is to find the infamous master of disguise, Dr. Futsch. There are 8 distinct disguise items and Dr. Futsch randomly chooses 3 of them for his disguise. Other players try to guess who Dr. Futsch is from 56 possible choices.
One year later published as Disguise (same graphics).
Re-implemented by
Das lustige Detektivspiel für Kinder

16631.description:
"Global Pursuit is a game of strategy and luck for those who enjoy learning about the world we live in. With four different levels of difficulty, it's also a game the whole family can play!

The object is to race your opponents around the world in your balloon, picking up your flags (in the correct order of course) by throwing the dice, answering questions and moving forward.
First player to collect all seven flags is the winner."
16631.name: Global Pursuit

16632.name: GOPS
16632.description:
GOPS is a simple bidding/bluffing game played with an ordinary pack of cards, with all the hearts removed.

One player takes all the spade cards, and the other all the clubs. The diamonds are shuffled and placed face down in the center of the table.

The diamond cards are turned over one by one. The players simultaneously bid for each diamond card with one of the cards in their hand (Aces low), and the player who bid highest takes the diamond card. If there is a draw, the next diamond card is turned over and the players bid again, the winner taking both the new diamond card and the one from the previous bid. If the final bid(s) end in a draw, neither player takes the last card(s).

When all cards have been played, the players count the value of the diamonds they have won. The Ace scores 1, Jack 11, Queen 12, and King 13, while the number cards score their face value. Whichever player has the most points wins.

16633.name: Spider-Man Vs. Doc Ock
16633.description:
Spider-Man is up against the evil Doc Ock in this exciting new game of racing and capturing. Every player takes on the role of Spider-Man jumping onto buildings and swinging along special spaces.
Get to the clock tower and attempt to rescue Jane from Doc Ock. Fail and you may go back to start. Succeed and you can race to the finish. Don't let Dock Ock thwart your attempts to succeed.

16634.name: Cyberpunk Episode I: The Battle For Cyber-dump
16634.description:
Not much detail on this game in English but here is a list of components:


3 assembling Hunter (linear 1) cyborgs
3 assembling Hunter (linear 2) cyborgs
3 assembling Harverster (bug) cyborgs
3 assembling Harverster (spider) cyborgs
10 walls of junk to be erected on the playfield
Two-sheets 90x60 cm playfield
88 play cards
2 pools for play cards
A set of bullets for shooting
D6 playing die
32 pages rulebook with legend story

16635.description:
The legendary 3D cricket table-top game is back......and, now it's better than ever.....with stylish improvements that'll knock you for 6!!!!

The all-new Super Cricket 3D table-top game now features:


A spring loaded bowler that can bowl the ball from different heights & at different speeds (the ball actually bounces) so you can select a different style of bowler for each over.....just like the real thing!



A trigger action batsman (no more strings in this all-new version!!!)



Magnetic fielders (so, no more disputes as to whether the ball has actually been caught or not!!!!) Contents:
1 trigger action batsman
1 spring loaded bowler
1 magnetic wicket keeper
9 magnetic fielders (4 standing, 5 crouching)
1 cricket pitch
