1 boundary rope & boundary rope holders
2 balls
1 set of score sheets & rules
16635.name: Test Match (second edition)

16636.name: Only Fools and Horses
16636.description:
"Only Fools and Horses" is a Monopoly style game based on the BBC TV comedy series of the same name.

You move around a monopoly style board encountering spaces or drawing "goods","chance", of "location" cards depending on where you land and gaining (or losing) money as you go.

16637.name: Sypil
16637.description:
French 2-player abstract game from Jacques Le Floc'h.

There are three types of counters in the game (triangles, hexagons and circles. These counters can be moved on the matching designs located on the board. They can also pile up and in that case their powers accrue. A triangle-hexagon can so move as a triangle and as a hexagon.

1 Hexagonal board
9 pieces per side (3 triangle, 3 hexagon, 3 circles).

16638.name: La Forteresse
16638.description:
From the box:
- Gain Territory
- Organise your troups for attack
- Assault the fortress of your opponent.

Contents:
- Game board
- 12 yellow pieces
- 12 red pieces

16639.name: Le Dé En Folie
16639.description:
Capturing game in which the goal is to be the last player with pieces remaining. Pieces move orthogonally only, changing direction after each step. Capture is by replacement.

Contents:
- 1 board
- 12 pieces
- 1 die

16640.description: Tactical combat between clay monsters you create.
16640.name: Monster Squash

16642.name: Big Breakfast Vital Statistics
16642.description:
"Big Breakfast Vital Statistics" is a card based trivia game with a difference. It is based on the "Stats and Facts" feature of UK Channel 4's Big Breakfast TV show presented by Johnny Vaughan and Denise Van Outen

The game has very obscure trivia questions such as "that only 28 per cent of pet stick insects are call Sticky but 42 per cent are called George" or that "40 blind people are registered to drive cars in Palermo."

The aim is not to get the answers right, but to be closest to the correct answer.

16644.name: On the Buses
16644.description:
"On the Buses" is a board game based on the hit 70's UK television situation comedy of the same name.

A game of fun and skill, the object being to "drive" your bus around the board and get three passengers back to the bus depot to win, but watch out for Blakey!

16645.description:
The AADA Vehicle Guide, "2034 edition", contains 129 pre-made Car Wars vehicles in various classes. In addition, there are 133 optional configurations giving a total of 262 possible vehicles. The Guide also includes an index to Car Wars weapons and gadgets, hints on customizing vehicles, new rules for off-road combat, and new rules for three-wheeler vehicles.

Part of the Car Wars Series.

Expands:

Car Wars
16645.name: Car Wars Supplement, The AADA Vehicle Guide
boardgameexpansion: Car Wars Expansion Set #6, The AADA Vehicle Guide Counters

16647.name: Form Line of Battle
16647.description:
Form Line of Battle
A Naval Entertainment

A set of simple instructions for fleet engagements in the age of sail.

From the Introduction section (page 2)"This game contains a number of novel mechanisms designed to capture the flavor of naval conflict in the great age of sail. We freely admit that they contain a touch or two of "Hollywood," but they should give you plenty of excitement, some doubts, uncertainties, stress and confusion. Record keeping is minimal and a fairly large fleet action can be fought in two or three hours."

Players are advised to furnish the following:
A handful of six-sided dice, some 'broadside fired' markers made of white cotton and some 'on fire' markers made of colored cotton. Three red and three black cards from an ordinary pack of playing cards. Finally, two fleets of 1/1200 or 1/3000 scale model ships.

The 16 page rule book contains the following sections:
1) Introduction
2) The Playing Area (on a table top)
3) The Sequence of Play (control, moving and firing randomized by draw of the six cards for either the 'red' or 'black' player.
4) Wind Direction
5) Sailing Attitudes
6) Movement (1 to 5 D6 based on attitude to wind and class of ship)
- Turning
- Tacking
- Anchoring
- Shoals and Shallow Water
- Re-floating after Running Aground
- Falling Masts
- Cutting Free a Fallen Mast
- Collisions
- Grappling
- Cutting Grapples
- Captured Vessels
- Boarding
7) Firing
- Broadside Firing Results Table (rolling 2 D6)
- Fire (i.e. ship catches fire)
- Damaged Steering
- Command and Control
8) Wind Direction Spinner
9) Point of Sailing Indicator (player aid)
10) Broadside Indicator (arch of fire player aid)
11) Fallen Mast Indicator (player aid)

16648.name: O Jogo Legal
16648.description:
The players simulate the practical one of the diverse types of professionals of the Law & Order: lawyer, judge, prosecutor, commission agent, notary, solicitor, appeals court judge, etc. The tray inside represents the chronological evolution of the life social of citizen and of the Brazilian society. It has a sequential division in five distinct phases. In each phase, it has a branch of the Right that predominates. The player will win the departure who to cover first the tray all, reaching the ending of the game. If the player to make right the reply, gains a bond of honor to the merit. If the given reply she will not be correct, the player goes for the space of the "burden of payment" and he does not advance in the tray.
The site of game is: http://www.estudebrinque.com.br/jogo/index.htm

16649.name: Prickly Pile-Up
16649.description:
From the box:

Particularly Perilous Prickly Pile-Up

A stacking game for all the family, Ages 5 and up

16650.description:
Security Station was MicroQuest #5 in the Metagaming MicroQuests series, programmed adventures for Melee and Wizard.

This one has a science fiction theme.

Expands:

Melee
Wizard
16650.name: Security Station

16651.description:
Master of the Amulets was MicroQuest #7 in the Metagaming MicroQuests series, programmed adventures for Melee and Wizard.

Expands:

Wizard
Melee
16651.name: Master of the Amulets

16652.name: Game of Catch
16652.description:
The Game of Catch which was produced in Toronto, Ontario, Canada in th 1970s by the Arico Playing Card Company.

Included in the flap-top box are instructions and information for parents in both English and French. The box is 9.2cm long x 6.cm wide x 1.5cm thick

Card backs contain drawings of sea creatures. The front of each of the 32 cards in the deck (8.9cm long x 5.8cm wide) contain drawings of fish, walrus, lobsters, crabs, whales, etc.. The name of each sea creature is printed on the bottom of each card. Colored dots related to the play of the game are in the corners of cards.

This game is currently part of the collection of the Games Museum at the University of Waterloo, in Waterloo Canada.

16653.name: Know Canada's Heroes
16653.description:
This game was manufactured in Paris, Ontario, Canada by the Walker Press, Ltd. in 1967 as one of the objects made available during the Canadian Centennial Celebration. The instructions and other text appears in both of Canada's official languages - English and French.

The flap-top box is 8.7cm long x 6cm wide x 1.3cm thick. The box includes the official Centennial Celebration symbol which can be seen in more detail on the back of each card.

There are 4 instruction cards in the deck which offer details for playing four different games with these cards. Each card is 8.5cm long x 5.5cm wide and features a date of note in Canada's history and a sketch of a person who played a role at that time in the history of Canada. Below the sketch are some historic details about the time period and the person's role. The various numbers and symbols on each card relate to playing the games.

This game is part of the collection of the Games Museum at the University of Waterloo in Waterloo, Canada.

16654.name: Oh! Canada
16654.description:
This multi-faceted colorful bilingual game was issued without charge to schools and citizens who requested a copy from the Commissioner of Official Languages of the Canadian Federal Government's Language Development Program.

All of the components of the game fit into the cardboard game board, which when closed is a large envelope that is 35.7cm long x 31cm wide. The game was created by Madeline Knonby and illustrated by Geo Boka, copyrighted 1974.
The game board when open is 35.7cm long x 62.3cm wide and about 1cm thick, and is a stylized map of Canada. Each province and territory (of the time) is in a different color and major cities are indicated on the map appropriately. In addition there are colorful scenes depicting various activities across Canada. Some places are indicated with their names in English and others indicated with their names in French. Different types of lines between cities illustrate modes of transportation between cities. For example, the dotted black line at the bottom between Winnipeg and Regina indicates a railroad, while the double red lines from Winnipeg going east indicates a highway; the yellow line from Churchill going northwest indicates an air-route and the white and black line going northeast indicates a water-route! The "legend" at the lower-left side of the board indicates these transportation modes as well as moves of players during the game.

The spinner on the board indicates the transportation modes a player must use while attempting to travel across Canada. The 32 page included bilingual book contains instructions for playing the game and other bilingual information. The game is for four players (illustrated in circles on the front of the book), each of whom is represented during play by a 1.5cm diameter plastic disc of white, green, red, or yellow.

The 33 1/3 RPM phonograph recording (17.8cm diameter) includes 2 songs in both English and French. There is also a glossary of phrases in both languages which includes phrases such as: "It's snowing", etc.

This game appears to be a modified later version of an earlier game - From Coast To Coast, but an earlier version of The Great Game Of Canada.

16655.name: Quick Draw McGraw Card Game
16655.description: Quick Draw McGraw was manufactured by Edu-Cards Manufacturing Corporation, New York City. There are 36 cards in the deck, each 9cm long x 5.8cm wide. Cards are numbered one through ten in the upper right and lower left corners. Each card has circular symbols in the center representing one of four "suits" and matching the number printed in the corners. The circular symbols are supposedly "bullet holes" - the result of McGraw's ability. The "Ace" or number one card features a sketch of "Quick Draw McGraw", with the words Lucky One printed across the top and bottom of the card.

16656.description:
Somewhat like snakes and ladders, the object of Quick Draw McGraw is to move your characters and be the first to reach the ranch. Alternate paths provide detours or shortcuts, and movement is governed by a spinner. The players' pieces are characters from the TV Cartoon show. This game is not the same as the 1960 Quick Draw McGraw Private Eye game, which used a similar mechanic but a completely different board.
Recommended Ages 5 - 10
16656.name: Quick Draw McGraw Board Game

16657.name: Game of Rebellion
16657.description:
Game of Rebellion was produced by Heyer Brothers, Boston, Massachusetts (US) sometime in the early years of the 20th century.The subject matter of the game is the American Civil War.
The game is for two or more players. There are 50 cards (5.8cm long x 9cm wide), and 7 "counters (1.7cm)". The cards are divided into 3 "suits" - red, blue, black - which have significance in the play of the game. On each card, the name of a prominent political or military personage of the time appears, or the name of a city which was the scene of a battle. The cards, counters, and instructions are encased in a box 11cm long x 7.6cm wide x 1.7cm high .

This game is part of the collection of the Games Museum in Waterloo, Canada.

16658.name: Star Hooks
16658.description: Players score points by adding stars to their solar systems and hooking stars with star hooks.

16659.description: Golf with a deck of special cards.
16659.name: Teed Off

16660.name: Archieball
16660.description: A strategy game where players are dealt hands of cards containing specific patterns, and a central trough of white and dark colored balls sits in the middle of the table between all players. Each player on their turn is allowed to lift one ball out of the tray and place it on either end of the line. Because the tray is slightly curved, all the remaining balls bunch together. Players try to win pattern cards by moving the wooden balls to match the card pattern.

16661.name: Trade Wars
16661.description: Score as many points as possible by getting the cards that complete any list or lists found on the cards.

16662.name: Great Divide
16662.description: Build a railroad empire connecting farms, ranches, mills, & mines and earn more money than the other players.

16663.name: Dora the Explorer Scavenger Hunt Game
16663.description:
Meant to be played individually or as teams, the game consists of 100 task cards each of which lists four items to acquire or tasks to perform. Half of the cards are for indoors and half for outdoors scavenger hunts. Tasks could be anything, such as the following:

- Bring back something that has a checkered pattern.
- Build a house out of Lego building blocks.
- Find a watering can.
- Stretch elastic bands over a board and try to play a song as if it were a guitar.
- Make up and draw a flag for the city or town you live in.

The game also includes player-task stickers with Dora the Explorer characters on them.

Ideal for parties or groups of children. Adult participation encouraged.

16664.name: Read'em
16664.description:
From the box:
Read'em is a family game that combines the skill of word building with the thrill of poker. The object is to win chips from other players by creating the best "hand" or by bluffing your opponents into thinking you have the best hand! Can a clever wordsmith outplay a wily poker bluff? Who'll win all the chips? That's the fun and excitement of Read'em!

Contents of the box
The game comes with a deck of 54 letter cards, poker chips and the rules to play 3 different poker games. You get the rules for Five Card Draw, Seven Card Stud and Hold'em (Hold'em is based on Texas Hold'em).

16665.name: Seejeh
16665.description: Game of capturing your opponent's pieces by first placing your pieces strategically and then moving them strategically.

16667.description:
Treasure of the Silver Dragon was MicroQuest #4 in the Metagaming MicroQuests series, programmed adventures for Melee and Wizard.

This one included a real world treasure hunt.

Expands:

Melee
Wizard
16667.name: Treasure of the Silver Dragon

16668.description:
Treasure of Unicorn Gold was MicroQuest #6 in the Metagaming MicroQuests series, programmed adventures for Melee and Wizard.

This one involves a real world treasure hunt.

Expands:

Wizard
Melee
16668.name: Treasure of Unicorn Gold

16669.name: Lotto: The Friendly Farm
16669.description: Six beautiful illustrated games boards introduced children to trades, numbers, fruits, vegetables, animals and miscellaneous items. Silhouettes on the back of the boards add a new dimension to the game, stimulating abstract thinking and perception. The aim of the game is to fill the game board with randomly selected cards.

16670.name: Sir Hinkle Funny-Duster, the Comical Game
16670.description:
The game is played with a deck of 20 cards divided into four FAMILIES; The Funnyduster Family, The Butler's Family, The Huntsman's Family, and the Gardener's Family. With 5 cards to each family, there are cards for the father, wife, son, daughter and the family symbol.

Cards are shuffled and dealt evenly to all players. Each player in turn freely asks any player for a specific card, if that player has the card asked for, the player must give that card to the person asking. Play continues for the asking player until the person asked does not have the card asked for and the turn goes to the next player.

Once a set of Family cards is collected it is laid on the table and retired from play (scoring no points for the player). The object is to be the player that lays down the last Family set

A twist in the mechanics of the game adds fun to the gameplay. Anytime a card is given to a player, the receiver must say "Thank You", if the receiver fails to do so, the first person to say "Duster" receives all of the cards from the person that neglected to say "Thank You". The person receiving the cards must in turn say "Thank You" or is subject to the same "Duster" rule.

The person that did not say "Thank You" and lost all of their cards can not be spoken to. They do not get any additional cards, but if someone speaks to this person, then the first person (any player) to say "Duster" receives the cards of the person that spoke to the person with no cards (and again, "Thank You" must follow receipt of the cards or the "Duster" rule applies again)

16671.name: Munsters Drag Race Game
16671.description:
A very simple roll-and-move mechanic driven by a spinner propels cardboard stand-ups of the Munsters TV Show Characters around the track.

VERY rare and highly sought after by collectors.

16672.description:
An expansion for the Gear Krieg Wargame base game that extends the system to the North African Theater. Includes:

- Alternate Historical Background for the Desert Conflict.

- Table Top Rules for fighting in the Harsh environment of Africa.

- 7 detailed desert scenarios with maps.

- Basic TO&E (Tables of Organization and Equipment) for the expeditionary forces of Germany, The British Commonwealth, the United States, Italy, and France.

- 50+ vehicles and variants from all nationalities.

Expands:

Gear Krieg Wargame
16672.name: Gear Krieg: African Theater

16673.name: Over the Top, Command Decision Series Game
16673.description: Over the Top is the WWI version of the original 1986 Command Decision (WWII operational level miniature rules). Uses platoon level stands and a vehicle scale of 1:5. Uses the same basic system as the WWII counterpart but also covers special situations specific to WWI (trench warfare, air power, chemical warfare, tanks).

16674.description: A new Basic Game to replace the Basic Infantry Game that quickly went out of print. This one feature four scenarios covering action in Normandy involving the 101st Airborne Division. There is a new Basic Game map for this game as well as complete Basic Game rules. Several scenarios have two versions, one for those who only own this game and another that provides extra units (tanks, jeeps, MGs) for owners of Against All Odds.
16674.name: Advanced Tobruk System Basic Game 1a: Screaming Eagles

16675.name: The Full Monty
16675.description:
"The Full Monty" is a boardgame based on the award winning film of the same name.

The winner of the game is the first player to get a job - but you may have to go the full monty before you finish the game!

First, ensure all the players have the same number of clothing items. Gather together a selection of clothing, the more bizarre, the better and place them in a pile on the floor, this pile will be known as the kitty. Before you begin the game, decide your group's criteria for The Full Monty. Is it as it should be, totally naked, in the buff, or will you chicken out and go down to underwear only? The choice is yours!

16676.name: Ad-Mad
16676.description:
Ad-mad is a mime and acting based game based in the wacky world of television advertising. The game is played on a board featuring eight "rooms" and each player has their own room and television remote control.

Cards that look like televisions invite the players to sing, mime or enact some of the most memorable and funniest product advertisements.

High standard antics are awarded with "buttons" for the remote control, and players move around the boards in search of a full set of buttons.

16677.name: Top Gear Motorsport
16677.description:
Top Gear Motorsport is one of several board games based on the popular BBC UK television series Top Gear hosted by Jeremy Clarkson.

The object of this racing trivia game is to be the first past the chequered flag at the end of an agreed number of between 1 & 11 laps.

Movement around the circuit depends on answering some pretty tough motorsport questions. Get the answer right and your foot is on the accelerator, get it wrong and you are going backwards!

Though (motoring) trivia based there are many variables which can improve or reduce your chances of winning: The circuit itself is tortuous so keeping to the racing line is essential. Hazard and weather cards, which can turn the track into a skid-pan make life interesting so choice of tires is critical, as is choice of fuel.

Game Contents:-
1 x playing board
1 x blue dice
1 x red dice
6 x coloured lap counters
6 x coloured racing helmets
388 x motorsport cards
12 x tyre cards
1 x set of red rocket fuel tokens
1 x set of blue fuel tokens
1 x lap counter board
1 x rules sheet

The box notes describe this game as a fast action game of skill, strategy, and racing knowledge.

You need a very good general knowledge of motorsport to enjoy this game to the full, but the rules include a shorter, faster version of the game can be played by using only the hazard cards and no questions, making game-play much less difficult.

16678.description:
This wargame is a part of the Micro Warfare Series covering World War I naval combat. It is a miniatures-style game that includes cardboard ship counters. The rules include both Small Action (individual ship command/gunnery) and Fleet Action (squadron command/gunnery) rules. Specific counters are included to fight the Goeben Incident, the Falkland Islands, Dogger Bank and the battle cruiser action at Jutland.

Supplements
Naval WWI
TTG-MN-101 British Jutland Set
TTG-MN-102 German Jutland Set
16678.name: Micro Fleet: World War I

16679.name: Pirater & Skatter
16679.description: Move around on a pirate map, and collect as much treasure as possible.

16680.name: À la carte
16680.description: Two teams compete in three events. Get the right ingredients for a specific dish, general questions on food and organize different products according to how nutritious they are.

16681.name: Fame Game
16681.description:
From the box:
"What do you know of actors, Ferrari-cars, exotic destinations, movie-lines, champagne and everything else connected to a life in fame."

16682.name: Magnus Magnusson the Quizmaster
16682.description:
Based on the BBC quiz programme "Mastermind", Magnus Magnusson presents the ultimate quiz with 10,000 questions.

There is no board or dice. The box with the questions in is simply passed from one player to the next each acting in turn as quizmaster.

The 10,000 questions are arranged into ten colour coded categories:

Famous People
Common Sense
History
The World
Stage and Screen
The Sciences
Sports and Games
The Arts
The Animal World
General Knowledge

The questions themselves have been designed to intrigue and arouse curiosity and so are interesting to ask. The answers are often unexpected, sometimes incredible, sometimes obvious.

The ultimate quiz game may be played by an unlimited number of people.

16683.name: Sign It!
16683.description:
From the game website:

Sign It! the board game is an interactive new way of learning and practicing American Sign Language (ASL). It is designed to be fun and educational.

Sign It! was born out of necessity. The creator is a 50 year old cabinet maker with a progressive hearing loss. While taking ASL classes, he searched in vain for a teaching tool to help him and his wife practice ASL and increase their vocabularies, and subsequently developed Sign It! to fill this need.

The Sign it! board game which includes a board a rule booklet and markers for six players, provides instruction for learning 824 signs. The game also comes with a copy of "Signing Illustrated" :The complete learning Guide, a 258 page illustrated and indexed reference book.

Sign It! contains a set of cards (which cover more than eight categories), a rule booklet, one die and markers for six players.

The game is setup reminiscent of Trivial Pursuit, with color coded squares.Each person gets a token (I was the elephant) then rolls the die. As expected,what ever the number you rolled...that's the number of spaces you moved. The color of the square is the color you look at on the card. Then you sign that word.

Colors are categories such as feelings, communication, locations, and more.On the card next to the words are page numbers for the accompanying book where you can find the appropriate sign. The game can be purchased with the reference book, "Signing Illustrated" by Mickey Flodin, which includes well drawn illustration, clear directions and even little reminder hints to help you remember new signs.

16684.name: I Giochi del 2000: Posto di Combattimento
16684.description: This is a little but complete set of rules about naval tactical combats in W.W. II, this 32-pages booklet contains also all the characteristics for naval and aircraft units for Germany, UK, Italy, France, Japan and USA

16685.name: Solomon's Treasure
16685.description:
This is a family game where each player is a "verb" traveling though the mines of Solomon trying to find Solomon's Treasure. King Solomon (from the Old Testament) was both a very wise and very wealthy king. In this game you are both seeking his monetary treasure and learning from his treasure of wisdom as found in the book of Proverbs.

The game is for Ages 8 and up but includes rules for younger children.

16686.description:
"QUICK DRAW is trying to solve some of the mysteries that he has heard about. He needs the help of the players in this game to find the missing parts to each mystery. Each player will use one of QUICK DRAW'S friends, BLABBER, SNOOPER, BABA LOOEY, or DOGGIE DADDY to help him."

Players take turns spinning the spinner and moving around the board. The space they land on determines which pile they draw a card from. Players may challenge other players for cards, and even steal cards from other players' hands. The first player to collect all eight puzzle cards detailing their assigned mystery wins.
16686.name: Quick Draw McGraw Private Eye Game

16687.description:
Spider-Man is a basic Memory game with a few twists. First, there are 48 cards, including two 'Wild Cards' that may match with anything turned over. Second, there are two pairs of 'trick destroyers' that take a trick away from a player. Finally, there are 5 pairs of 'Take Spider Man' cards that allow a player to capture the Spider Man figure.

Spider Man is worth 4 Tricks at the end of the game.
16687.name: Spider-Man 2 Make a Match Game

16690.name: Diabological
16690.description:
Simple fantasy-themed abstract strategy game from the mid-80s, when such things weren't as popular as they are now (early 2000s). Published in the last issue of Warlock magazine, number 13.

The board depicts the classic demon-summoning layout, with pentagram and magic circle. One player is the wizard, the other, the demon; both are armed with tokens, two for each ancient element (earth, air, water, fire). The wizard plays first, setting up his elements hidden at the points of the triangle and pentagram with no opposing element on the same line. The demon plays second, laying down one element at a time next to the wizard's and seeing what happens before playing the next. The idea is that the wizard should create a difficult-to-guess defense, while the demon tries to solve the puzzle and/or hedge his bets.

16691.name: The Addams Family: Find Uncle Fester! Card Game
16691.description:
The search for Uncle Fester is on!

The object of this card game is to collect all seven members of the Addams Family: Gomez, Morticia, Lurch, Pugsley, Wednesday, Thing, and Uncle Fester. There is only one Uncle Fester card, which makes collection of a complete set difficult. You cannot win if you are holding the Tully Alford card (he's the devious family lawyer).

In addition, there is an action card deck, which instructs the players to ask for, search for, trade, and pass around cards. Recommended for Ages 8 and up.

16692.name: Strategy Rummy
16692.description:
Strategy Rummy is described as "a bet and bluff game." This game was published as a follow-up to another MB game: Strategy Poker.

Strategy Rummy is played using a vinyl table cloth, mini poker chips, and a special deck of cards (which includes six wild cards). Each player is dealt seven cards and everyone antes one chip into the pot. The sequence of play is as follows:

A. Draw a card
B. Discard a card
C. Place a meld or lay off cards onto the vinyl table cloth
D. Ask for bets from opponents.

Players go out by playing all seven cards from the hand onto the vinyl cloth. The player with the most chips wins the game.

16693.description:
From the publisher:

Ever played UNO underwater? Now you can, with UNO H20. Waterproof cards and carrying case let you take this easy, fast-paced family game to the pool, beach or anyplace that's wet.

For 2 to 10 players, Ages 7 and up

--

UNO H20 includes two new cards: Wild Downpour 1 and Wild Downpour 2. When played, all other players must draw 1 or 2 cards, respectively. The player of the card also determines the new color.
16693.name: UNO: H2O

16694.description:
Orm's Return is the first Large Figure Expansion Set (wave 2.5) in the HeroScape series. It was released with the Terrain Expansion Road to the Forgotten Forest.

There is 1 large booster pack:

Heroes of Laur
16694.name: Heroscape Expansion Set: Orm's Return
boardgameexpansion: Heroscape Master Set: Rise of the Valkyrie
Heroscape Master Set: Swarm of the Marro

16695.name: Griddly Headz: Hockey Game
boardgamepodcastepisode: The Spiel #68 - That's A Wrap - 2008 Holiday Gift Guide
16695.description:
One of seven in the line of Griddly Headz Boardgames, Hockey sees a different cast of “Griddly Headz” (regular Joes) duking it out on the ice for ultimate supremacy.

Played on a large, two-tiered board, Griddly Headz features the chance to choose both your team and how your individual players match up against your opponent’s.

Gameplay consists of numerous dice challenges that take place when two players meet on the same play square of the board; the loser forfeits a piece of their equipment (represented by puzzle pieces). If a player loses all twelve pieces of equipment, or one of their Griddly Headz is ejected from play, they are immediately eliminated from the game.

To win, you must score 10 goals.

Available in Special, Deluxe, Family, and Mini editions.

16696.name: Always Play Fair!
16696.description:
From the publisher's website:

Pick your favorite Packy PlayFair game piece, spin the wheel and see what the cards have in store! Each card teaches a valuable lesson in sportsmanship and fair play. Read the game card and if Packy does the right thing you move ahead - a slip up will send you back! If you spin and land on a space that matches your Packy game piece you spin again! But be alert as you move around the board - there are twists and turns that will either help you toward the finish line or hold you back! You pick the best course to follow.

Be the first person to move around and collect all the letters of PLAY FAIR and win the game!

Winner of the Creative Child Magazine Seal of Excellence 2004

16697.name: Kiss My Rules!
16697.description:
Paraphrased from the Publisher's Website:

Kiss My Rules!™ is comprised of two poker-style card games (Straight and Flush) and two fun dice-shaking games.

As players win rounds, “behavioral” rules are added to the game-play. Some examples of rules are:

"No Swear Words.", "No Pointing with your Finger." "No crossing your arms or legs."

Will your opponents catch you or will you get away with it? As the game progresses, you’ll have many of these rules in effect at the same time. You’ll be afraid to speak or even move. If you’re really good you’ll be able to trick other players into breaking the rules.

Some of the Rule Cards allow you to make up your own rules. All new rules begin as “Community” rules and must be obeyed by all players. But if you’re lucky enough to draw a rule-changing card, you can give any rule to any player you choose to pick on. Now only that player has to play by that rule. But revenge is mighty sweet since there are several of these cards, and you may soon find yourself on the receiving end.

16698.description:
From the publisher:

Iron Cow 2103AD

2103AD. Earth is a ravaged planet... The effects of nuclear war, ecological disasters, greenhouse warming and resource exploitation are plainly obvious, but still man finds excuses to fight over whatever is left. Then, with the creation of a viable FTL drive, man embarks on a new wave of colonization into space. Nations, power-blocs and mega-corporations now attempt to secure their place in the stars, usually by means of a kinetic energy cannon...

Written by Steve Blease, Iron Cow 2103AD is a simple but challenging set of fun science fiction wargames rules that are ideal for anyone looking to start wargaming using 6mm (1/300th or Epic) SF vehicles and figures, or for more experienced wargamers who just want a quick simple game that works, without needing to wade through pages and pages of table, rules, sub-clauses etc, etc.

With a purpose designed background, Iron Cow 2103AD is ideal for anyone who wants a set of rules with which to use the wide ranges of excellent 6mm models available from a variety of manufacturers. However the rules are flexible and simple enough to be tailored to any SF background, using whatever SF figures & vehicles you choose...
16698.name: Iron Cow 2103AD

16699.name: Such & Such
16699.description:
All the answers are in twos!

In Such & Such, teams try to solve a set of five clues. All of the answers are things that go together. For example, “The two youngest Brady kids” (answer: Bobby and Cindy); coffee complements (answer: cream and sugar); and motto of The Three Musketeers (answer: All for one and one for all).

To play, one team member reads five clues to his teammates, who then have 40 seconds to solve them.
Teammates may pass but will not be allowed to return to the clue. When time runs out, the opposing team has the chance to steal any passed clues and any clues that were not answered before time ran out. The first team to reach 25 points wins. Such & Such is for four or more players who play in teams.

Ages 10 and up.

16700.name: Take a Gamble
16700.description:
Take A Gamble features classic and new versions of poker, blackjack and craps (7-11). It also includes original games of chance called Gambler’s Row™ and Roll for the Jackpot, as well as Take A Gamble Cards offering 30 games of chance. It’s non-stop action with all games played in rotation as players land on board squares and all players join in each game. The winner is the player with the highest value in poker chips at the end of the game. Take A Gamble™ is designed for 2 to 8 players, age 19 or older.

The game box includes: full-color game board, deck of 52 playing cards, 5 dice, 300 poker chips, 30 Take A Gamble™ Cards, jackpot bowl, 8 playing pieces and a detailed game guide.

16701.name: Birthday Gamesake
16701.description:
Birthday Gamesake™ is a way to annually celebrate a child’s birthday or to honor a milestone birthday — 13th to 95th. Add cards annually to a child’s Gamesake™ and it becomes a dairy of their life.

It’s easy and fun to create! Before or during the birthday celebration, family and friends record their favorite memories of the birthday honoree on the enclosed gift cards. The board can also be personalized for the birthday honoree by labeling destinations and creating new ones.

It’s unique to play! Birthday Gamesake™ follows the life of the birthday honoree from birth (bassinet) to the cake. The personally created gift cards (recorded by friends and family) move the players through the board. The first player to reach the cake wins!

16702.name: Christmas Gamesake
16702.description:
Paraphrased from publisher's website:

Christmas Gamesake™ is designed to be played every holiday and before long you’ll have a diary of your family’s greatest memories!

It’s easy and to create! During the holiday season, create the Gamesake™ by filling out favorite memories from the year (or years past) on the enclosed gift cards. If you have young children, record oral stories and document special family achievements. Personalize your board by labeling important locations in your family’s life.

It’s unique to play! Follow Santa’s journey around your world and the first player to land exactly on the North Pole wins. Laugh at the memories on the personally created gift cards as players move along the board path.

16703.name: Trick Track Troll
16703.description:
You are a Trolling. Try to get through a mystic wood, where the paths are rotating (die roll) to get your key from the opposite side of the board , rush into the mine, get your crystal , run home and win the game .
The game is very well produced, but consists only of rolling dice.

16704.name: AirWar: 1918
16704.description:
From the publisher:

Written by David Manley and Matthew Hartley, AirWar: 1918 is the second in a series of introductory level air combat rules (following on from AirWar: C21)based around the same innovative core system.

Utilizing a unique 2D system to recreate the 3D maneuvers of dogfighting, AirWar: 1918 is a perfect introduction for the newcomer to the fun of air wargaming as well great for the more experienced 'old hand' looking for a simple yet enjoyable set of rules to introduce his 'groundpounder' friends to war in the skies.

AirWar: 1918 includes historical scenario ideas from Great War and Russian Civil War air battles as well as data tables for many aircraft in service during the Great War for Britain, France and Germany, as well as some from Russia and Italy.

AirWar: 1918 is a set of Great War wargames rules for use with any scale models from 1/72nd to 1/300th. Combining playability with relaism, they provide gamers with a simple yet challenging game of Great War air warfare, retaining the spirit of the period, without sacrificing the speed and excitement.

Includes:

A 2D system that recreates the manouveres of 3D dogfighting.
Rules to cover ground attack, rockets, balloon-busting and zeppelins
11 scenario ideas based on historical incidents from 1915 to 1919..
Statistics for over 50 aircraft from Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Russia.

16705.description:
From the freely downloadable PDF:

AirWar: C21 Lite is a cut down version of the second edition of AirWar: C21, our popular fast play, “entry level” set of rules for dogfights set in the years after WW2, and for near future SF games. The rules use a quasi 3D manoeuvre system, whereby the action is fought out in 2D, but with some representation of 3D air combat manoeuvres.

The Lite version is intended to give you the basics of the game and allow you the opportunity to try out some dogfights using the AirWar: C21 system between US F-14 D Tomcats and Russian Su-27 Flanker B’s.

Player notes:

A hexless tabletop miniatures game with each miniature representing a single aircraft. The system breaks game turns into two phases, with each aircraft moving & attempting a manoeuvre in each phase. Turn summary (edited from PDF):

Phase 1
• Select and apply engine power speed changes (unless stalled)
• Roll for initiative, conduct radar/visual spotting
• Move (if turning, move half the aircraft Speed, turn, and move the second half)
• Test for and execute all movement or manoeuvres in order of initiative
• Resolve effects of any missiles launched last phase
• Launch new missiles
• Resolve air-to-air gun or rocket attacks
• Resolve speed changes due to manoeuvre or stall recovery
Phase 2
• identical to Phase 1

Tests for manoeuvres vary in difficulty, making a Barrel Roll easier than an Immelman, etc.

The system uses multiple D6 & D10, single die rolls for tests, detection, etc, multiple for damage. Speed, damage & currently carried weapons are the only variables during play, but each aircraft & weapon has many values to record before starting. Although simplified from the full rules, the system includes a large variety of factors to simulate air warfare, with only the lack of altitude tracking being a notable abstraction.

Only statistics for the F14 Tomcat & Su27 Flanker and their weapons are included in the Lite rules.
16705.name: AirWar: C21 Lite

16706.name: Firewall 2136AD
16706.description:
From the publisher:

2136AD... The future is a dark, grim and violent place. Amongst the conurbs of the English Republic, criminals, corporations and para-military law enforcement teams battle each other in a never ending struggle to make a quick E-Cred. Technology and science are used to provide the edge - whether through a new weapon, an implanted cybernetic enhancement or a non-recreational drug. Life is cheap on the streets of 22nd century England. Just make sure it�s someone else's life...

firewall 2136AD is a set of science fiction skirmish wargames rules, designed to allow gamers to fight out battles in a cyberpunk inspired future, using any of the wide ranges of excellent 25/28mm scale models available from a wide variety of manufacturers.

So for all fans of William Gibson, Blade Runner and even Akira, here's firewall 2136AD...

Written by Matthew Hartley and Michael Baumann, firewall 2136AD lets players create teams of criminals, police and corporate security teams, arm them, cybernetically enhance them and even drug them up, before letting them loose on the tabletop to gain hegemony in their own fictional cyberpunk world.

The rules not only cover infantry combat on the streets but also include full vehicle rules, how to fight inside buildings and one of the most impressive arsenals of tabletop firepower, protection and cybernetic enhancements seen in a set of skirmish wargames rules.

16707.name: Futbowel
16707.description:
From the publisher:

Written by Matthew Hartley and Steve Blease, Futbowel is the game of fantasy football ie. based on the proper game, not some variant with body armour, a big egg and using your hands!

Futbowel is a light hearted, fun and simple game to recreate the games between 22 orcs and a pigs bladder that occur on muddy fileds across The Land. The rulebook includes a brief history of Futbowel, details of thirteen famous Futtie teams from the Bladez to the Wightz, famous Futtie sayings as well as rules for the tabletop recreation of the noble game of Futbowel.

Futbowel is a complete game comprising of rulebook, twenty-two orc 28mm futbowlers, one orc referee (with fowl) and a scale model pigs bladder for them to kick around.

16708.name: Gangland
16708.description:
From the publisher:

Written by Matthew Hartley and Steve Blease, Gangland is a set of wargames rules from Wessex Games, allowing you to recreate the gang battles that raged in the inner cities of the western world throughout the nineteenth century, as well as the fights against the forces of the establishment that occurred in cities like London, Paris and New York.

As well as providing a comprehensive set of rules to recreate the battles of the period, Gangland also contains five introductory scenarios, illustrating the depth of the background in which these rules are set:

New York 1834 - join the Bowery Boys as they attempt to smash their way past the Dead Rabbits .

Chicago 1897 - meet the Irishers and Bohemians, two gangs of school kids who fought a lethal twenty-five year long gang war.

New York 1857 - the most bizarre gang war of all with two New York police forces fighting each other and attempting to free each others prisoners.

San Francisco 1875 - defend the honor of the Suey Sing Tong against the insults of the Kwong Dock Tong.

London 1887 - strike a blow for social freedom against the repression of the British government by marching on Trafalgar Square.

16709.name: Hellfire
16709.description:
From the publisher:

Written by Jim Webster, Hellfire is a unique set of 6mm SF wargames rules. Generic in nature, Hellfire differs from other products in this field in that it is scenario driven rather than points based - the emphasis being on putting the fun back into gaming.

A very comprehensive set of rules, Hellfire allow you to play the game you want to play, in the setting you want to play it in. by covering a wide range of possibilities from troop reactions at night and nuclear warfare to psionics and machine intelligence.

The ground breaking reaction system that governs exactly how your troops behave on the battlefield accurately simulates how prolonged exposure to combat saps at even the best of troops emotional resilience and reflects the grind of real war. Additionally the system allows you to have aliens and androids that act in an un-human fashion and not as men in rubber suits or tin cladding.

The rulebook also contains four diverse scenarios illustrating the flexibility of the system and appendices on models and figure availability for the game, and SF combat literature as a source of scenario ideas.

16710.name: Panzerfäuste
16710.description:
Panzerfäuste is, in the most basic terms, a miniatures game where standard fantasy races replace humans as the protagonists in WW2 “German” Dwarves, “French” Gnomes, “British” Orcs etc. although the influences stretch across most of the first half of the twentieth century.

Originally published as a section level skirmish game in 1998 by Wessex Games, two new versions of the game are currently being worked on by Hysterical Games:

A second edition of the skirmish game, and;

A new platoon level (30 to 50 figures a side) Mass Battle game.

16711.name: Ranke & Vyle
16711.description:
From the publisher:

Valon is at war... the Usurper Emperor Morded leads his musket weidling columns of Elven infantry and squadrons of noble cavalry against the rest of Valon. Orc fights alongside Dwarf in a desperate bid to hold back the Elven armies, the battlefields are shrouded in smoke as flintloques and artillerie smash the ranks and files of disciplined warriors. It is a time of war - it is a time of desperation.

Ranke & Vyle is a set of Company level Black Powder Fantasy Rules set in the world of Flintloque - the Skirmish. Written by Flintloque's author Steve Blease, Ranke & Vyle takes you the next step up the rung of command, tasking you with maintaining your troops in cohesive units and recognisable formations, balancing situations and getting maximum usage out of your troops.

Ranke & Vyle contains full rules for Company level actions including mass uni firing, formations and unit movement as well as introducing Wyld Magick users onto the battlefield with all the unpredictability that comes with them. Racial statistics are also included for thirteen races ranging from Orcs to Halflings, and one hundred and twenty-seven different troop types. Ranke & Vyle also includes six challenging scenarios set in the Mordredian Wars to start you off with.

This edition of Ranke & Vyle is a limited edition product and only 300 numbered and signed copies will be made available worldwide.

16712.name: Scudbusters II: Return to Iraq
16712.description:
From the publisher:

Scudbusters II: Return to Iraq is a set of modern Special Forces combat rules which combine playability and realism in an attempt to provide gamers with a simple yet challenging game of Special Forces warfare based on the experiences of Allied Special Forces troops in the Gulf and Iraq Wars.

So if you read Bravo Two Zero or where just intrigued by the TV coverage of combined US Special Forces-Peshmerga operations in Northern Iraq, here's Scudbusters II: Return to Iraq...

Written by Matthew Hartley, this new edition of the popular Scudbuster rules expands beyond the original game, which covered SAS operations in the Gulf War, to include all Allied Special Forces and their activities in the 2003 Iraq War. The rulebook also includes options to extend to operations in Afghanistan and even hypothetical actions in "Axis of Evil" countries such as North Korea.

In the game the player takes control of the Special Forces units and operate in an increasingly challenging environment as fatigue and casualties take their toll the longer your troops are in the field. The Iraqi forces are controlled by reaction tables and can be as unpredictable as in real life.

Scudbusters II contains AFV rules, ambush tables and strategic level rules that allow gamers to link missions together as they happened in the war.

Reaction tables for Iraqi regulars, Baathist fanatics and Fedayeen Saddam are also included in the rulebook as well as rules to include Kurdish Peshmergas operating on the side of US Special Forces.

16713.name: Strange Grogge
16713.description:
From the publisher:

Strange Grogge is a set of black powder fantasy skirmish rules, designed for 28mm scale battles between orcs, dwarves, elves and other popular fantasy races.

Written by Mike Baumann, Matthew Hartley and Steve Blease Strange Grogge is set in Wessex Games� fantasy realm of The Land, centering around the pirate infested region known as The Barbarous Coaste.

In the game the player creates and takes control of either a band of pirates or government troops and fights out any of the frequent skirmishes that take place in the towns, jungles, lagoons and islands that make up the Barbarous Coaste.

The rulebook also contains optional role-playing rules to provide even more detail for players, especially those who have a hankering to be the infamous Dwarf pirate Shortbeard or other famous personalities.

Strange Grogge contains numerous weapons options, a swashbuckling melee system, four different types of magic (from gastronomic to singing sea shanties) and a campaign system .

16714.name: Strange Tydes
16714.description:
From the Publisher:

Written by Matthew Hartley and Steve Blease, Strange Tydes is a fun and simple game to play of fantasy age of sail naval warfare. Use ships based on historical equivalents of the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries, the way only an Orc or Dark Elf can. Pit the wooden walled men o'war against the erratic ironclads of the Dwarven principalities. Encounter sea monsters and face strange magick on the oceans of The Land. Play the only game we know of where you can kill the opposing vessel's ship's parrot!!

All you need to play Strange Tydes is a copy of the rulebook, a selection of models (though cardboard counters can be used), some dice and a flat area on which to play.

The Strange Tydes rule book contains:

Complete tabletop rules for naval battles between the various races of The Land, including Ironclads, Fortifications, Fire Ships and Magick.

Full background details including a map of the treacherous region known to all as The Barbarous Coaste.

Details of all the races of The Land fighting on the seas of the Barbarous Coaste during the Wars of Dwarven Succession.

Naval Lists of the various fleets involved in the Wars of Dwarven Succession with full details of crew and vessel availability.

Three introductory scenarios set on the legendary Barbarous Coaste.

16715.description:
From the publisher:

Written by Matthew Hartley, Steve Blease and Mike Baumann, Voyages Extraordinaires is a simple game to play, with the emphasis on the players having a good time, rather than becoming bogged down in rules minutia. Whereas other Victorian Adventure Games games have tended to concentrate on the more recognized military aspects of the period, Voyages Extraordinaires is geared more towards adventuring, through the use of our unique turn sequence and archtype character profiles.

All you need to play Voyages Extraordinaires is a copy of the rulebook, a handful of miniatures, some ten sided dice and a flat area on which to play.

The Voyages Extraordinaires rulebook contains:
The basic rules for adventures in distant realms and a combat system that allows for human characters to successfully battle large beasts such as elephants and dinosaurs, as well as the inhabitants of Mars and Venus .

An optional complete exploration time line from 1788 to 1899, mixing fact and fiction.

Character templates for over a hundred different character types with their unique traits.

Three introductory scenarios following the adventures of Professor Peterson, the most noted scientist in the Empire.
16715.name: Voyages Extraordinaires

16716.name: Squadron Commander 3600
16716.description:
From the game's site:
SCALE: Tactical. Time and distance scales unstated. Each model represents an individual spacecraft.
PERIOD: "3600 A.D., a time when fragmented human empires first come into contact with an alien menace (the Vallarri)."

"This game is a space fighter boardgame for which custom miniatures are available. Players can design their own fighters or use pre-designed plans. Weapons include lasers, cannons and missiles; defenses are armor and shields. Fighters move in an order determined by their tactics and the pilot's skill level, and firing can take place during movement. Damage results in critical hits, which limit or eliminate ship systems or wear the starcraft down until structure failure occurs. Rules allow players to form squadrons, then fight a series of individual battles or a linked campaign. Background material (optional) details six human empires and one alien power."

The Game's Components consists of the following:
'56'-page rulebook (includes record forms)
'4'-(four) 11" x 17" mapsheets (black with hexgrid)
'2'-(two) countersheets (counters must be cut out)
The game includes a rule book with rules for both Basic and Standard games. Two full-color countersheets are included along with a hex-map so that you can start playing immediately. Dice are not included. Three 6-sided dice and one 10-sided die are required for the Basic game, while the Standard game requires one 4-sided die, three 6-sided dice, one 8-sided die, one 10-sided die and one 12-sided die.
The rulebook contains 21 pre-designed fighters, each associated with one or more of the political entities of the 37th century. Although an official set of miniatures is available, these rules are suitable for use with any space fighter models of appropriate size.

boardgamecompilation: Hounds and Jackals: Game of the Pharaohs
16717.description:
Ancient Board Games is a collection of four popular board games which were played in the days of the pharaohs in ancient Egypt and in nearby countries from about 5000 years ago. It contains the following games:

Hounds and Jackals
Senet
The Royal Game of Ur
Mehen, the Snake Game

The games are presented in an oversized cardboard book with plastic playing pieces included.
16717.name: Ancient Board Games

16718.name: Fuzzy Heroes
16718.description:
Fuzzy Heroes is a rule book for a miniatures war game using stuffed animals and toys. From the rulebook:

"Fuzzy Heroes is a family fun game of combat for stuffed animals and toys. Although it is not as serious in outlook, nor as rooted in realism, as most miniatures games, it does contain all of the basic elements of any miniatures game."

16719.name: Manhattan
16719.description:
Magnificent wooden game where you try to gain influence in Manhattan building the highest skyscraper. You roll two dice and move your two pawns so that you can build a new floor or a roof or you can place a street tile.

If you can manage it that your building (higher) and the one of an opponent could merge you take over the building.

Some additional rules make this a very nice 3D variant of ACQUIRE

16721.name: Star Hop: Game of the Cosmos
16721.description:
Ages 10 and up

Components: Game Board (Milky Way Galaxy + more), Instructions, Star Hop Decoder, Star Hop Navigator's Manual, 4 Rocket Playing Pieces, Mission Cards, Hop Cards, and GNC Cards.

Object: The object of Star Hop is to be the first player to acquire 25 Galactic Navigation Credits (GNC's). Players are awarded GNC's when they successfully complete missions described on the Star Hop Mission Cards.

Description: Players become space travelers and visit the solar system, comets, black holes, super-giants, quasars, and other galaxies. It's a fun and competitive way to learn of the discoveries of modern astronomy.

16723.name: Crystal Maze
16723.description:
The Crystal Maze is a board games based on the popular UK Channel 4 TV game show of the same name that ran from 1990 to 1995 and was hosted by Richard O'Brien (of Rocky Horror Show fame)

Move around the board and battle through the challenges of the four time zones: futuristic, medieval, Aztec and industrial winning challenges to gain "time crystals" that buy you time and take you to the final challenge to win gold in the Crystal dome.

Contents:

1 Crystal Dome
1 Crystal timepiece
1 Gameboard
4 Playing Pieces
4 Timezone walls
Gold Tokens
Silver Tokens
16 Time Crystals

16724.name: The Tequila Game
16724.description:
Components:

Folding Board, Playing Pieces, Border Wars Ammo, Question Cards, Dice, Instructions.

Publisher's Description:

"THE SCENE IS SET ON THE MEXICO/TEXAS BORDER IN THE 1800'S. EVERYONE IS ON THE WRONG SIDE OF THE LAW; ROBBING BANKS, FIGHTING, GAMBLING, CHEATING, SMUGGLING, - AND DRINKING!

This colorful game allows you to criss-cross over the border robbing banks for bags of cash (providing you have the ammo), Drinking Beer (in Texas), Margarita and Tequila (in Mexico). You may turn your Best Friend Over To The Law for a reward, perform a Mexican Hat Dance, start a Mexican Wave, answer questions on Tequila and Mexico, play Strip Poker, have a Gun Fight, perform Crazy Mimes, Tongue Twisters, and Kiss Everyone. - All in the first 15 minutes."

Brief Notes:

Obviously, the beverage of choice to drink in this game can be adjusted to fit the crowd playing. For those easily offended, the "Strip Poker" segment does not need to go overboard, so this can make for a decent party game among almost any crowd of reasonable adults.

16725.name: The Vodka Party Game
16725.description:
Components:

Folding Game Board, Playing pieces, Playing cards, Dice, Full Instructions

Publisher's Description:

"You're inside the iron curtain. The Cold War is on. You must eliminate your own 'super villain', acquire by various means secret documents on microfilm and get out alive. As a secret agent, licensed to kill, you are prepared to do anything to win. Watch out for the double agents secretly working against you. Copious amounts of drinking and eating to be had!"

Brief Notes:

The beverage of choice can be adjusted to the crowd playing (and doesn't necessarily have to be vodka), so this makes for a decent party game among any crowd of reasonable adults.

16726.name: The Beer Game
16726.description:
Components:

Folding Board, Playing Pieces, Question Cards, Dice, Instructions.

Publisher's Description:

"You will travel around the board, in and out of the Irish bar, the village pub, the club and the tavern having a drink and collecting bottles along the way. You may have to arm wrestle someone, perform some bar or magic tricks and do unimaginable feats in varied and interesting ways. You could take a booze cruise or a serious bar crawl. You might just end up in the gutter, fall asleep with your clothes on or land in jail - or you may just have to drink lots of beer!"

Brief Notes:

Non-drinking friends with a sense of humor can still enjoy this game by substituting a beverage of choice for beer. Enough fun and interaction to be a decent party game for any group of reasonable adults.

16727.name: Play on Wordz
boardgameversion: MB Spiele German edition in red box
Milton Bradley "Games to Take With You" series edition
16727.description:
A set of 9 lettered dice are rolled simultaneously and players form as many words as possible as quickly as possible with points scored for non-duplicated words and for longer words.

Each player tries to form 10 words with at least four of the letters shown, thus ending the round. Each word that only one player wrote scores a point; additional points are awarded for longer words; points are deducted for misspellings or using letters not shown.

Play on Wordz is a word dice game.

Similar to:

Stellar Speller (which has 7 dice instead of 9, and is sold by Discovery Toys)

16729.name: A Night at the Dogs
16729.description:
Components:

Folding Game Board, Set of 6 Dogs, set of "DOG" cards, set of "FORM" cards, betting chips for 8 players, race meeting cards and instructions.

Publisher's Description:

"Its a gamble! Study the form (different for each race), check the odds (favorites don't always win) and place your bets! Betting chips are provided so you don't have to bet with real money.

Fortunes to be won or lost! By studying the odds you may have more chance of winning -but, just as in real life, the outsiders can take the race -so a lucky name or number, a whim or a fancy, can sometimes serve you just as well!

The "Dogs" run against the turn of a set of specially formulated cards which automatically adjust the odds and form, which is determined before every race, so that the outcome of each race is as predictable (and unpredictable) as in the real world of dog racing.

Each race lasts around 5-8 minute. There are 10 races per card but you can play as many races as you like as each is excitingly different and unpredictable.

This really is an exciting game and you don't know the outcome of each race until the last card is played!"

Brief Notes:

Fast and interesting wagering game. Since you can play as many races as you want, it can be as quick as 10 minutes, or an all evening game if you wish.

16730.name: Derby Dog Race Game
16730.description:
Components:

Folding Game Board, Blue Cards, 6 Greyhound figures

Description:

This is a very old dog-racing wagering game published by "The Cardora". All game play was determined by a set of cards, which dictated odds, events, and race results. The ceramic greyhound figures look good if in good condition.

16731.name: Movie Mystery: Raiders of the Tomb of Death
16731.description:
Components:

Screenplay Award Statue, 10 sided 'Decider', Directors Audio CD, 10 Cue Cards, 10 Contracts / Invitations, 1 Hosts' Party Planner, 10 Character Profile Cards, 10 Identity Badges, 10 Screenplay Nominations Cards, 10 Envelopes, 10 Pencils, Instructions

Publisher's Description:

"It’s 1924. A train is traveling through Egypt towards the ancient city of Khartoum. Among the passengers are a bunch of adventurers who, though strangers, find themselves in the same hot and cramped compartment of the dusty train. A conversation is struck and an uneasy association is made as they realize they’re all heading for the same place -the ancient site of THE TOMB OF RAMITIN. Perhaps they all have the same secret aim -to bring back the famed diamond which, according to legend, is hidden in the vault. BUT several mysterious deaths have occurred at the site and the place is now known as the..THE TOMB OF DEATH!

The players are the Adventurers. They will act out SEVEN SCENES, working from instructions given by the DIRECTOR (on the audio CD). They arrive on set 'in character', each with their own secret identity (sealed instructions sent out by the host(s) with the invitations). The evening culminates in THE SCREEN PLAY AWARD CEREMONY a magnificent affair where players are judged in three categories; On their abilities to ACT, to IDENTIFY CHARACTER TRAITS IN OTHERS and to DISCOVER THE SECRET.

The winner will keep the prestigious SCREEN PLAY AWARD STATUE."

Brief Notes:

This is one of a series of "Movie Mystery" games, which work well at parties with people who enjoy mysteries and a little bit of play-acting. Role-playing gamers can easily take to this as well.

16732.name: Movie Mystery: Never Die Forever Again
16732.description:
Components:

Screenplay Award Statue, 10 sided 'Decider', Directors Audio CD, 10 Cue Cards, 10 Contracts / Invitations, 1 Hosts' Party Planner, 10 Character Profile Cards, 10 Identity Badges, 10 Screenplay Nominations Cards, 10 Envelopes, 10 Pencils, Instructions

Publisher's Description:

"The mad, evil Doctor Bloefaert is up to his tricks again, trying to take over the world -this time by controlling the weather. As an experienced CI5 agent with special skills, you have been commanded to join a crack team who will infiltrate the evil organization, de-activate the "weathertron" and blow up the private volcanic island base in the pacific. But things don’t run so smoothly and the excitement and danger builds up to a climax as you interact with your comrades in arms in frightening situations. You are exposed to temptations in exotic locations -this may be your last mission, you may..
.......NEVER DIE FOREVER AGAIN

The players are the Agents.They will act out SEVEN SCENES, working from instructions given by the DIRECTOR (on the audio CD). They arrive on set "in character", each with their own secret identity (sealed instructions sent out by the host(s) with the invitations). The evening culminates in THE SCREEN PLAY AWARD CEREMONY a magnificent affair where players are judged in three categories; On their abilities to ACT, to IDENTIFY CHARACTER TRAITS IN OTHERS and to DISCOVER THE SECRET.

The winner will keep the prestigious SCREEN PLAY AWARD STATUE."

Brief Notes:

This is one of a series of "Movie Mystery" games, that can be a great party game among people who like mysteries and a little play-acting. Role-playing gamers can easily enjoy this as well.

16733.name: Movie Mystery: The Sinking of the S.S Titania
16733.description:
Components:

Contents: Screenplay Award Statue, 10 sided 'Decider', Directors Audio CD, 10 Cue Cards, 10 Contracts / Invitations, 1 Hosts' Party Planner, 10 Character Profile Cards, 10 Identity Badges, 10 Screenplay Nominations Cards, 10 Envelopes, 10 Pencils, Instructions

Publisher's Description:

"It’s 1912, the new age of travel. You are young(ish), attractive, fashionable and are captivated by the idea of travel to far off places, with the opportunities for adventure, romance and love. You have a ticket for the maiden voyage of the S.S. Titania sailing from Southampton to New York. Once on board you find yourself in the company of people like yourself with similar expectations. At the Captains’ table, in the casino and in the luxurious bars and lounges, the adventure and romance unfolds as you interact with your new found friends -though one of them is not all he (or she) seems. Then tragedy strikes, all hell breaks loose and all must face the awful reality of what they said could never happen...
THE SINKING OF THE S.S. TITANIA

The players are the passengers. They will act out SEVEN SCENES, working from instructions given by the DIRECTOR (on the audio CD). They arrive on set 'in character', each with their own secret identity (sealed instructions sent out by the host(s) with the invitations). The evening culminates in THE SCREEN PLAY AWARD CEREMONY a magnificent affair where players are judged in three categories; On their abilities to ACT, to IDENTIFY CHARACTER TRAITS IN OTHERS and to DISCOVER THE SECRET.

The winner will keep the prestigious SCREEN PLAY AWARD STATUE."

Brief Notes:

This is one of a series of "Movie Mystery" games, that can be a great party game among people who like mysteries and a little play-acting. Role-playing gamers can easily enjoy this as well.

16734.description:
Components:

Screenplay Award Statue, 10 sided 'Decider', Directors Audio CD, 10 Cue Cards, 10 Contracts / Invitations, 1 Hosts' Party Planner, 10 Character Profile Cards, 10 Identity Badges, 10 Screenplay Nominations Cards, 10 Envelopes, 10 Pencils, Instructions

Publisher's Description:

"It’s the year 1858. In a small, isolated village inside a forest in deepest, darkest Transylvania stands a small medieval tavern where our story begins. It’s through an encounter here that you and other like-minded travelers of fortune manage to get jobs at the castle on the hill belonging to Count Dracenstein. But soon, things start to get a little strange and you and your fellow workers are exposed to a host of horrifying situations. You realize, perhaps too late, the true intentions of the Count and soon discover the real secret of..THE BLOOD OF DRACENSTEINS’ CASTLE

The players are the Workers. They will act out SEVEN SCENES, working from instructions given by the DIRECTOR (on the audio CD). They arrive on set 'in character', each with their own secret identity (sealed instructions sent out by the host(s) with the invitations). The evening culminates in THE SCREEN PLAY AWARD CEREMONY a magnificent affair where players are judged in three categories; On their abilities to ACT, to IDENTIFY CHARACTER TRAITS IN OTHERS and to DISCOVER THE SECRET.

The winner will keep the prestigious SCREEN PLAY AWARD STATUE. "

Brief Notes:

This is one of a series of "Movie Mystery" games, which work well at parties with people who enjoy mysteries and a little bit of play-acting. Role-playing gamers can easily take to this as well.
16734.name: Movie Mystery: The Blood of Dracenstein's Castle

16735.name: Hide 'n' Thief
16735.description:
Be the first player to find two moneybags, put them into a truck, and reach the bank without being robbed!

Players take turns hiding their moneybags under their colored houses. Then roll the dice to move your van, and peek under any of the other players' houses -- find a bag of loot and add it to your van! But if you find a thief instead, you lose the loot you've already collected (which is hidden again by its owner) and return to your start space.

Fill your van with two bags, and head toward the Bank -- but if you land next to a house, you MUST look under it. A third bag of loot won't help you, but a thief can turn your big lead into a bust.

Components: 20 houses, 4 trucks, 8 moneybags, 4 thieves, two six-sided dice, one gameboard.

16736.name: The Grid
16736.description:
From the publisher:

The Grid is a board game, officially licensed by the Federation of American Football Leagues (FAFL). It simulates the excitement of Yankee Rules football, as players take control of their favorite teams and players. Each of the twelve teams in the 2050 FAFL World Tournament is represented by its complete 15-man roster. Play out your own tournament, and see if you have what it takes to coach your team to the championship!

16737.name: Union Pacific
16737.description: Players attempt to build a cross-continental railroad route using a spinner and miniature plastic track sections. Cards are used to delay your opponents.

16738.name: Engineer
16738.description: Players use a spinner to determine the movement of their engine in attempting to navigate across the rail yard and hook up with their set of cars.

16739.name: Space Bug
16739.description: Roll a die and put a peg in your space bug, until all the pegs are in place. Each number on the die is associated with a particular body part on the bug.

16740.name: Grand Fleets
16740.description:
From the publisher:

Grand Fleets is a comprehensive miniatures game of dreadnought-era naval warfare. In addition to rules for everything from ships to aeroplanes, Zeppelins to submarines, the rulebook includes:

Data cards for over 120 ships, plus guidelines for converting any ship of the period to game values;

Eight scenarios encompassing conflicts from the Sino-Japanese War of 1894 through the opening salvoes of World War Two, including several variants;

Fifteen pages of weapon data, covering all major gun and torpedo models in use through 1939, over 200 aeroplanes, and more than 20 airships; and
Optional rules for flotillas, night-fighting, smokescreens, and more!

boardgamehonor: 1979 H.G. Wells Best Miniatures Rules Winner
16741.description:
System 7 Napoleonics is an extension of miniatures wargaming with printed counters substituting for the miniature figures. The scale is 1"=40 yards. One "strength point" (the equivalent of a single miniatures figure) represents 20 infantry, 20 cavalry, 10 artillery crewmen or two guns. Infantry counters are 1¼" wide (50 scale yards), with 10 counters typically comprising a regiment. Turns are notionally about an hour each.

The system is based on GDW's Fire & Steel rules, with modifications for the distance scale and features such as stacking that are impossible with figures. GDW published 15 counter sets, all for the period from 1808 through 1815.
16741.name: System 7 Napoleonics

16742.name: The Interstate Haul Trucking Game
16742.description: Players pick up commodities and deliver them, moving around each other and encountering obstacles.

16743.name: The Sovereign Stars
16743.description:
Combining the epic scope of Twilight Imperium with the excitement and adaptability of Starmada, The Sovereign Stars contains three major components:


First, the races of Twilight Imperium are fully defined within the Starmada rules system, including starship designs, weapons, and equipment.
Second, it adapts the races outlined in the Starmada rulebook to Twilight Imperium, giving players the opportunity to decide the future of the Terran Empire, the Arcturan Federation, and the major players in the Starmada universe.
Finally, The Sovereign Stars contains guidelines for linking tactical battles in Starmada with the strategic level of Twilight Imperium, letting players control the destiny of their empires at multiple levels of play.


Expands:

Starmada

16744.description: "Battalions In Crisis" is a World War II tactical miniatures game based on the old TSR "Tractics" rules.
16744.name: Battalions In Crisis!
boardgameexpansion: SkirmishElite: Screaming Eagles at Hamburger Hill

16745.name: Defiance
16745.description:
From the publisher:

Welcome to the Defiance Universal Skirmish System™, the game of near future and science fiction tactical combat that lets you modify or even create the strategic setting in which your battles will take place. With force sizes varying from one unit to several platoons, each trooper matters, and the correct combination of mobility, firepower, command and control is crucial to your success.

The U.S.S. Army Customizer is a comprehensive and statistically based force construction tool that literally allows you to design any weapon, any trooper and any army that you can imagine, all the while being assured that your creation will be balanced for play against any other U.S.S. force list. A lot of work and testing went into the Customizer, and we feel that you will not find a more versatile or more balanced universal force construction tool on the market today.

The 128-page rulebook contains the necessary rules and army lists to allow players to take part in the battles for the Milky Way. Control the ground forces of one of 5 different empires, all jockeying for supremacy in the new power vacuum that the Starslayers have created:


The Vobian Empire, vast and ancient, which utilizes high-tech weaponry and cybernetic beasts to even the odds against its former subjects.
The Tamerlane Khanate, progeny of the last great Mongol Empire, which still clings to a tribal past, despite the urgings of its human neighbors.
The Ka-yi Sultanate, Perseus heir to the Ottoman Empire, which struggles against religious and political tradition to form a united Human Confederacy.
The Nordic Alliance, descendants of the army of Gustavus Adolphus, who have used ingenuity and military know-how to overcome their limitations and become galactic players.
The Meraxillan Empire, ever evolving, which cares only for its own expansion at the expense of all others.


This book contains rules which cover almost every tactical situation, including troop quality, command and control, army discipline, indirect and suppression fire, vehicles from mecha to armored personnel carriers, and more. Also included is the Starslayer Troop Builder, a complete and statistically-balanced troop construction tool that allows you to convert virtually any figure to the Starslayer rules system.

16746.name: Evolution
16746.description:
Team oriented party game that stresses divergent thinking, creative improvisation, and mental ability. Teams move around the board or "up the evolutionary ladder" by correctly completing a variety of 18 different challenges including drawing, rhyming, acting, miming, decoding puzzles, deciphering clues, identifying pictograms, reading minds, and predicting the future.

EVOLUTION also offers players the chance to increase the difficulty level for some of their opponent's challenges by either choosing the opponent to perform the challenge in SURVIVAL OF THE FITTEST or in coming up with their own unique and wild answer for the challenge in NATURAL SELECTION.

16747.description:
A dexterity dice game consisting of four sets of colored dice one either slides, rolls, or flicks down a stepped surface. Usually one slides the die for better accuracy. After each person has slid their 4 dice, points are scored. You score the die roll times a multiplier of either 1×, 2×, 3×, or 4× depending on which area of the board the die is on. (Dice which land in the 0× region are immediately removed from play.) High scoring rolls are targets for opponents. Four rounds are played and the player with the most points win.

Tumblin-Dice Jr. is the "travel" version.

The 2008 edition from Ferti Games states is for 2-6 players.
16747.name: Tumblin-Dice
boardgamepodcastepisode: BGA Ep 66 - If You Like Carcassonne, Try...
Episode 16 : BGGcon 2015 Recap - Codenames - Favor of the Pharoah - Time Stories
Episode 17 - Is That A Meeple In Your Pocket?
Episode 17:  Mysterium Review - Christmas Song - Giveaway - Christmas Wishes
Episode 72 March Craziness Dice Game Style Part 1
The Good the Board and the Nuts and Bolts: Episode 10
What Did You Play This Week Podcast Thing Week 26!!!

16750.name: Busy Bodies
16750.description:
From the publisher:

The outrageous mix-and-match game of quick-changing characters, cards, and scores! Collect body parts with the highest value around the game board to match your character. Beware, the board will bump you back, push you forward and switch your body part cards on every roll. Busy Bodies is easy to learn, fun for the whole family and guaranteed to crack you up on every play. Game includes 1 game board, 21 character cards, 42 body parts (3 make up a character with values 4 or 6), score pad, dice, 6 pawns and instructions.

16751.name: Sleigh Wars
16751.description:
With the increasing volume of deliveries to be made, Santa is unable to cope. So the powers that be advertised for additional franchise holders, with the result that there are now 4 Santas. Unfortunately they all have very different ideas of what the job involves, and of the right presents for people...

A 2-4 player game where each player takes the part of one of the 4 Santas and attempts to deliver 6 presents, one to each of 6 houses. Each present correctly delivered earns the player 2 points, while incorrect deliveries earn only 1. Presents left on the sleigh at the end of the game are worth -1 each!

Features Xmascette missiles, brandy flamers, Turkey Cannons and other weaponry!

Published by Games Workshop in their December 1985 issue of White Dwarf Magazine (number 72), this was a cut-out and play game.

16753.name: Operation: Veritable
16753.description:
From the Rules Introduction:

Operation: Veritable is an introductory level, two-player wargame on the battle for the Reichswald forest. It was fought during the second and third weeks of February, 1945. Despite the looming defeat the German's faced, the Wehrmacht was still able to put up a stiff defense.
