You can only move one ball in your own colour and only if it is lying alone in a groove or uppermost in the groove, i.e. nearest the centre of the board. It is NOT counted as a move, however, if by moving a ball to another groove it happens that the balls in this groove are of the same number and in the same colour sequence as in the old groove before the ball left it.

A player has lost the game if he or she has no possibility of moving.

16863.name: Pike City Arena
16863.description:
It is over 200 years since the first of the terran colonists landed on the uninhabited and unsuspecting planet of Neo-earth. Humans have begun to establish a new history of wanton destruction and unbridled creativity. The Singularity rift that eventually will lead to the establishment of a utopia is centuries away in the future. The fledgling nation of U.S.N.A. originally set up by the North Americans of old earth is fast becoming one of the most powerful of the industrial states.

As nations formed and the population began to be settled the media was there to cover it. Whenever a settler put a spade in the ground, wiped out a species or did something horrible to another human being a camera was there. The media became the chronicler of the pioneering years, and more. To forget the hardships of day-to-day living the Neo-earthlings immersed themselves in all forms of entertainment sims, V.R. and finally real combat TV. Beginning as fighting matches between professional athletes it quickly evolved to include audience participation. Teams of home viewers roamed across elaborate battlegrounds beating the snot out of each other for the sake of entertainment. These "teams" eventually became fighting orders with their own particular combat styles. As long as TV audiences could see a New Texan housewife savagely mauling an accountant from Maine with a pain-wand each week real combat TV continued to be a success.

Nobody knows exactly when FENRIR (Fusion Engine Non-Robotic Intercept Raider) was invented. Originally developed as support for conventional army forces, they began to be used in the frontier areas and in civilian "control" situations. The executives of the NABC (Neo-American Broadcasting Corporation) weren't slow to adopt this new technology and use FENRIR in their real combat events. Unable to construct artificial battlegrounds of a sufficient size the media networks purchased the ruins of Harmony, the former capital of the USNA state of Piermont that had been destroyed during the conflict with the Ontarians. In this city-sized arena the combatants now range across the landscape in giant FENRIR machines dealing devastation to the opposing team(s). The ultimate televised combat sport is born!

In PIKE: City arena each person controls one of the four major real combat "teams". The object is to crush the opposition while putting on the most entertaining show for the cameras.

16864.name: Dash Hounds Game
16864.description:
Just like the game's name...these four adorable, "growable" hounds really "dash" to win the race. The dogs are small at the start of the race...but as the race progresses they grow longer and longer. Unlike other races - the dog whose TAIL crosses the finish line first wins the game!

Players spin the spinner and move their dogs the appropriate number of spaces toward the finish line. If the front legs of a dog should land on a colored space, the player whose dog matches that color must add a section to his dog.

16865.description: THOSE RAGGED BLOODY HEROES depicts the bloody Pacific Island fighting on the northern coast of New Guinea. Here the Australian 7th Division has pushed the Japanese invader north in the long and bloody Kokoda Trail campaign. During the weeks prior to the battle for Gona, General Horii's defenders toiled long and hard to prepare a defensive ‘death-trap’ that awaited the oncoming—and unsuspecting Australian soldiers. Cleared fire-lanes, log bunkers and Japanese snipers await your men of the Australian 7th Division as you re-fight this tragic and controversial battle.
16865.name: Those Ragged Bloody Heroes. The Australian 7th Division at Gona: November 29-December 10, 1942

16866.name: Klin Zha
16866.description:
Klin Zha (Klingon chess) is similar to "Earth" chess in that it is an abstract board game between two players. Pieces move and capture opposing pieces like in chess. It is played on a triangular board with triangular spaces. Initial setup is free: players may arrange their pieces in any manner they choose within their section of the board.

Official website: http://www.tasigh.org/takzh/ (very outdated)

More recent website with extensive rule documents: http://www.klinzha.com

Online study tool: http://www.klinzha.com/study

On klinza.com, there's also a better ruleset that can be used with Zillions of Games. This ruleset is from 2010 and includes all twodimensional Klin Zha variants.

16867.name: Axis Threat
16867.description: Axis Threat is a DTP wargame on the German Counterattack at Gela in Sicily, 1943.

16868.name: Bodycount in Laos
16868.description: A DTP wargame on the Arvn (South Vietnamese army) incursion in Laos 1971.

16869.name: Pocket Trivia: Gen-X 80s & 90s
16869.description:
Trivia game about Generation X consisting of 52 cards with 16 questions on each card. Lots of 1980s and 1990s trivia.

One player takes the top card from the deck and reads a question aloud. The person to the card reader's left gives an answer. If incorrect, the next player (clockwise) guesses, and so on. If correct, the person who guessed correctly keeps the card; this person becomes the reader; he reveals the next card from the deck and reads it aloud. If nobody guesses correctly, the answer is revealed and nobody gets the card.

Play continues until no cards are left in the deck. The winner is the person who has the most cards.

16870.name: Das Prestel Säulenspiel
16870.description:
From Prestel web-site:

"May it be an Ancient Greek Temple, or a Roman Palace; a Renaissance Cathedral or an Opera, the columns always had a special part in the architecture. In this tile placing card game you will control the money, the construction and placing of the columns to make a perfect construction."

16871.name: Alquimix
16871.description:
From the box of the game: "In Alquimix, all the fantasy of ancient science become a thrilling challenge!
"Each player has 5 test tubes and color tokens representing chemical substances and cards. Using these cards players transfer one, two or three tokens from one tube to another. Their goal is to make proper combinations of colors, as depicted on the bottle cards."

16872.name: It's a Small World Game
16872.description: "The object of the game is to be the first player to reach the clock after having five cards on their proper spaces on the board."

16873.name: Dividends
16873.description:
From the publisher website :
"Make your fortune on the volatile stock market through stock buying to earn dividend payouts or selling for profits (capital gains). The key to success in this game lies in a player’s ability to make the most money from each stock purchase (maximizing return on investment) while taking into consideration the effects of supply and demand on stock prices (market economics). While being the first-mover confers tremendous advantage, exercising major shareholder influence on dividend payouts can perhaps give a player the added edge towards financial victory!"

16874.name: Vince Lombardi's Game
boardgamepublisher: Research Games, Inc. / Athol / RGI / ARC
16874.description:
"Vince Lombardi's Game" is a football simulation for two players that can be played on three levels. The basic game uses generic football teams. The intermediate game applies aggregate offensive and defensive ratings for the NFL/AFL team of each player's choice. The advanced game permits each side to use the individual stats for each NFL/AFL football player.

This game was published under the title "Vince Lombardi's Game" in 1970 and 1973, and under the name "Be a Pro Quarterback!" in 1971.

The latter variant is a bit of an oddity. The cover lists the maker as Sportsgames, the instructions list the maker as Sports Games, and the board lists the maker as RGI. Whoever published that edition, "Be a Pro Quarterback!" served as an odd placeholder between RGI's 1970 and 1973 Vince Lombardi football games. The rules of the game are the same as for the 1970 "Vince Lombardi Game" edition; only the players are different.

See also the 1967 version "Fran Tarkenton's Pro Football" by RGI, using the same plays and cards, but in a much higher quality format. (The cards are thick board, laminated, and backed with light felt. The plays board is full color on a stand, laminated so the play differentials can be listed by each play in grease pencil. That version also includes a down maker and a ten yard marker.)

boardgamehonor: 2005 Origins Awards Vanguard Innovative Game Award Winner
16875.description:
Darter is a quick strategy boardgame in which the players place tiles to affect the movement of 'darters', trying to destroy their opponent's base while protecting their own.

There are two categories of tiles; Impact tiles, which alter the course of the darter when struck; and Proximity tiles, which affect the darter when it passes through the tile's active squares.

Darter was showcased at GenCon SoCal 2004.

Re-implemented by:

Dragons of Kir
16875.name: Darter

16876.name: First Down!
16876.description: Before Tudor Games made its foray into a playbook-driven football game simulation, a Washington D.C. company known as TGD Games made its own version of a football game driven by play selection, "First Down!". In it, two players call offensive plays and set offensive formations in order to drive down the field and score, or set defensive formations to prevent the offense from gaining ground.

16877.name: Traffic Patrol
16877.description: One player controls an red "outlaw" car. The other player(s) control four gray "police" cars. The outlaw can move in any direction, while the police may not move backwards. The outlaw's goal is to escape the board; the goal for the police is to trap the outlaw or force him back to his starting space. No dice are involved. Instructions are provided in both English and French.

16878.name: 18 Wheel'n
16878.description: 18 Wheel'n is a promotional piece published by Roof Enterprises and presented by George Transfer Inc. of Parkton, Maryland. The object of the game is to be the first to get one's rig from their home city terminal to their destination terminal and back. Yellow spaces on the board require players to draw a card that can either help or hinder them.

16879.name: Battlefield Command
16879.description: Two players use tanks, helicopters, paratroopers, engineers, bridges, and infantry to achieve either full victory (elimination of an opponent's forces or Operations Command Center), or at least a tactical victory based on points should either of the main victory conditions no longer be achievable. Special advanced/tournament rules are also included.

16880.name: Escape From Pirate Island
16880.description: One player leads a Pirate fleet of 6 ships, while his opponent leads the King's fleet of 3 war ships, 2 life boats, and 9 merchant ships. Both sides have reserve forces that may come into play as well. Sea monsters (a giant squid and giant octopus) may be added to increase game complexity. The Pirate player wins by eliminating the King's fleet; the King's player can win via straight force elimination against the prates, successful transit of a merchant ship, or by capturing the Pirate's Treasure.

16881.name: Pacific Fleet Command
16881.description: Each player has 2 aircraft carriers, 5 dive bomber squadrons, a battleship, 5 heavy cruisers, 2 light cruisers, 2 submarines, 4 destroyers, 2 mine sweepers, 2 mine layers, and 2 construction battalion game pieces. A player achieves victory by destroying his opponent's 3 ship yards or eliminating his opponent's aircraft carriers, heavy cruiser, and battleship.

16882.name: Convoy Defender
16882.description: One player takes on the role of a submarine force commander, leading a fleet of six submarines. The other takes charge of a convoy of nine destroyers and three convoy ships. A hurricane and two tropical storms may also be added to increase game complexity. Victory conditions vary for each player: the convoy commander must eliminate the submarine fleet, while the sub commander need only reduce the convoy to a single ship.

16883.name: Adventures of Sir Lancelot
boardgamefamily: The Legend of King Arthur and the Knights of the Round Table
16883.description: This game is based on the NBC TV series of the same name. Two to four players compete in a "spin and move" venture to avoid pits, traps, a dragon, and the Black Knight as they head along the road to capture Camelot or Westbury Castle.

16884.name: Baseball Action
16884.description: "Baseball Action" uses a positioning and die rolling mechanism. Players have some latitude in positioning fielders and runners prior to the batter's die roll. The game may be played solo, with two players, or two teams of two.

16885.name: Big Time Baseball
16885.description:
Big League Baseball bills itself as "The World Series of Baseball Games." It uses a curious dice-rolling mechanism that allows players to try to place their fly balls, ground balls, and bunts on a spot of the field least covered by opposing fielders. Strategy comes into play on offense in strategically allocating dice for a fly ball; on defense with positioning fielders to optimally cover the field.

No production date is given, but one of the Sid Sackson collection copies of this game was marked as being acquired in 1983.

16886.name: Baseball's Greatest Moments
16886.description: Baseball's Greatest Moments is a game in which each player's knowledge of baseball trivia is put to the test. Two to six players buy "souvenirs" and "baseball memorabilia" with the answer points awarded for correct answers. The winner must acquire 1500 points in souvenirs/memorabilia, 100 points in answer points, and answer a final challenge question in the last zone of the game board.

16887.name: Capital Hill
16887.description:
"Capital Hill", as the title suggests, is a game of accumulating money through the political process. In the regular version, three to six players start with a randomly determined number of chips representing Senators and members of the House of Representatives. Each player directs their politicians to gain power and money by winning elections, holding onto power positions, and passing laws. Players are eliminated when they lose all their representation in the House and Senate. When only two players remain, the player with the most money is declared the winner.

A short version permits two to six players to compete for a fixed number of game rounds; again, the player with the most money at the end is the winner.

16888.name: Coloption
16888.description:
"Coloption" is also known as "Col*ption".

From the rules:

"COLOPTION is a fast paced adult game with some gaming elements familiar to generations of games players and new devices [...]. The object of the game, which is played on a geometrically designed game board, is to move your men from their home base to a goal. To do this, you must roll combinations of dice and color cubes and move your men through an exit triangle, hazard hexagon, safety zones, alien colors and goal paths. If that's not enough, there's also the danger of being 'bumped' by other players!

"COLOPTION can be played by two to six players which immediately makes it more sociable than backgammon which is played as a twosome. A round is over when all of one player's men have either reached the goal or been bumped. A round usually lasts from fifteen to thirty minutes. Play can be for several rounds as in backgammon or for point totals as in bridge."

16889.name: Conservation
16889.description: In "Conservation", players move their cars along the board's outer track, then the inner track, and then to their service station in the middle. Along the way, they face state fines and maintenance issues for their car. The game ends when a player reaches their service station, but the winner is the player with the most money at the end.

16890.name: Containment
16890.description:
"Containment" is a game played between pro-nuclear and anti-nuclear factions. Pro-nuclear players try to go "on line" and produce electricity; anti-nuclear players try to shut down the reactor and switch to alternate forms of energy production. A reactor in the center of the board moves either towards or away from meltdown as the game progresses, depending on the players' actions.

"Containment" may be played on three levels: a Basic game that is purely luck driven, a Standard game that uses arguments and counterarguments (given on the game board) in the nuclear power debate to influence game play, and an Advanced game that calls on the players to evaluate and rank their own arguments as well as those of their opponents.

The game is obviously inspired by the events at the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant in 1979, as one of the arguments given on the game board explicitly mentions TMI. The box cover artwork is also very evocative of TMI.

16891.name: Corvette
16891.description:
"Corvette" bills itself as "the automobile maintenance and trading game." However, it somehow feels more like a Chevy advertising piece, as each player progresses from owning a Cavalier through a Celebrity, Caprice, and Camaro in their quest to be the first to own a Corvette and be free of debt.

2-6 players compete in an admittedly simplistic game: collect money by passing "payday", then hope to avoid spending it all on car maintenance in order to buy a better car. Judicious selection of which "pick up" cards (coupons and special board advance cards) to keep in one's hand add a little strategy to an otherwise "roll and move" style game.

16892.name: Counter All Terrorists!
16892.description:
"Counter All Terrorists" challenges its players to defend against a series of terrorist attacks on the United States. The game may be played solitaire, or by up to six players. As the title suggests, the object is to counter terrorists' attacks on the "White House, Pentagon, CIA, FBI, Air Force One, and many military bases and cities across the United States."

It is an unusual title in terms of historical insight, having been published in 1986 and embellishing its instructions with Albert Einstein's quote, "imagination is more important than knowledge." The game treats a subject that few would take seriously at the time -- though, in hindsight, its designers also failed in imagination for the weights given the various terror targets.

16893.name: Decisions
16893.description:
From the publisher writeup:

"DECISIONS is an exciting and colorful new drug-prevention board game that teaches youngsters to use their own personal power to manage relationships that put them at risk. Perfect for use at home or in school, DECISIONS uses hard hitting, real-life scenarios to help participants experience the anxieties and emotions associated with making decisions about relationships that involve drugs."

The game places up to six players in various real-life drug-related situations and encourages discussion for these scenarios.

16894.name: Eccentric
16894.description:
"Eccentric" features a search for the elusive billionaire Mr. Who (a takeoff on billionaire Howard Hughes). In a manner similar to "Clue", players need to identify which city, hotel, and suite Mr. Who is in, along with which of his 5 disguises he is using.

From the game description:

"Somewhere in the Western hemisphere, the eccentric billionaire, Mr.Who, is hiding. Suspicious and withdrawn, Mr. Who is elusive to the point of being almost invisible.

"A Federal grand jury has just ordered Mr. Who to testify in court. Acting for the district attorney, three to six players are about to join in the exciting global search for the world's most fabulous recluse."

16895.name: FutureStories
16895.description:
From the game description:

"Storytelling often revolves around the past. But there's another type of storytelling that we call FutureStories. Imagine playing a game where you talk about your hopes and dreams for the future. What do you want to be doing five years from now? What will the world look like in 100 years? [...]

"FutureStories is easy to play and fun for all ages. There are no right or wrong answers. This game is based on your imagination, not intelligence, knowledge of trivia, or chance. And... it can be played anywhere."

16896.name: Gambit
16896.description:
Gambit is an abstract strategy game in the trappings of a war game. Players use jets, ships, amphibious vehicles, and rockets to seize an enemy goal square or eliminate their opponent.

The map for at least one printing is a bit of a curiosity. In it, the cover of the box shows a 10x10 board with alternating green and blue squares. The instructions note that the land squares are green and the sea squares are blue. However, the actual map provided is 10x16, has only black and white print on yellow paper, and uses the letters "L" and "S" to designate land and sea spaces. It would appear that the designer assumed he would be able to print color boards, but then had to fall back to a simpler black and white drawing printed on yellow paper.

16897.name: Game of Love
16897.description:
In this game, two to eight players compete by trying to out-romance each other. For the winner, the game notes, "Your reward is collecting a KISS, a BEAR HUG, or a HEARTY HANDSHAKE from the lover of your choice. (We suggest the winning lover and the chosen one leave the room for this.)"

While luck plays a factor in moving from the start space to the LOVE NEST goal, life experiences, memory, quick wit, and other factors can also help you advance. Some spaces call upon you to quote a line from a love poem (or complete a line for a provided rhyme) without repeating another player's answer. Others call on a player to correctly identify the eye color of the other players in the game. Still others feature bits along the line, "If you think your legs are pretty, go forward one. If anyone doubts you, prove it or go back two."

16898.name: Hat In The Ring
16898.description:
"Hat in the Ring" is a throwback to an era when political party conventions still were perceived to hold an important role in the nomination of each party's candidates.

In this game, three to eight players compete for their party's nomination; however, in a classroom setting, additional roles such as Campaign Manager, Treasurer, etc. may be assigned to other participants. Players go through a series of primaries, then try to gain the required number of delegates at their party's convention to win on a given ballot. Delegates are won in blocks of 10; a player must therefore claim at least 660 out of the 1,300 delegates to win a given ballot and claim the nomination.

16899.name: Is the Pope Catholic!?!
16899.description:
"IS THE POPE CATHOLIC !?! THE CATHOLIC NOSTALGIA GAME" offers 2-6 players the opportunity to test themselves (in a somewhat humorous vein) on pre Vatican II Catholic doctrine.

While it can be played as a trivia game by non-Catholics, a handicap is definitely in order if one of the players is Catholic... and, especially, an older practicing Catholic.

The object of the game is to be the first player to ascend the Papal throne by completing "a six-decade rosary" around the board and advancing through the Church hierarchy.

16900.name: Longball
16900.description:
"Longball" is a stats-driven baseball simulation in which the players draw up their lineups from contemporary (to the publication date) Major League players, then play out the game with those players' stats weighting each die roll result.

At least three different editions of Longball were released. The first edition was in 1975 by Ashburn Industries and offered cards based on the 1974 season and projected 1975 rookies. The second edition was in 1977 by Skor-Mor, and offered individual cards to represent each major league player's stats. The third was in 1979 by Ashburn Industries, which consolidated the player stats into 13 double-sided Team Roster cards.

The 1979 edition of Longball offers two levels of game play: the "Master" Game, an Advanced "Master" Game, and the Basic Game. Curiously, Ashburn gives the rules for the Basic Game last, reasoning, "Since the majority of the people who buy LONGBALL buy it for the ultimate in baseball accuracy, we will begin with the explanation of the Advanced 'Master' version."

16901.name: Lyle's Baseball Game
16901.description:
In 1991, Sheryl and Steve Shrout took one of Steve's old game ideas and worked it into an actual game product. The game, "Lyle's Baseball Game", draws its identity from Steve Shrout's middle name. It may be played solo or with two players. While the game is essentially a dice rolling contest, there are some amusing rules tossed in:

- No kicking dirt onto home plate.
- No spitting on the field.
- All rolls of the dice are final. No arguing with the dice.
- Seventh inning stretch optional, but suggested for couch potatoes.

16902.name: Megacorp
16902.description: In a manner slightly reminiscent of Milton Bradley's game of "Life", two to six players choose whether to follow a path of self-employment and eventual sellout to Megacorp, or a university program that leads them to employment with Megacorp. However, both paths eventually converge and lead the players onto the path of a corporate takeover. When all players have reached either the "Pyramid" or the "Over Budget" squares, the player with the greatest total of Common Stock Shares becomes the Chief Executive Officer of Megacorp and wins the game.

16903.name: Merit: The Catholic Game
16903.description:
In "Merit", two to four players work to build the six key properties (Church , Convent, Seminary, Catholic Charities, School and Foreign Missions) while maintaining their level of merits (700 points) and obtaining six of the seven sacraments. The first player to return home with the required six sacraments and at least 700 merit points after the six properties are built wins the game.

The question deck is filled with pre-Vatican II trivia, but also has cards that offer the player a chance to advance via deeds rather than answers (e.g., a card that allows the player to go to any square if they promise to say the rosary).

16904.name: Offshore Oil Strike
16904.description: Two to four players compete at exploring for oil, building platforms, and laying pipelines to bring the offshore oil back to the player's home company. Players take on the roles of either BP (Hull), Amoco (Bergen), Chevron (Rotterdam) or Mobil (Dieppe) in their quest for oil. As with other games focusing on offshore oil exploitation (e.g., Omnia's North Sea Oil), there is also the risk that storms will reduce production on, or eliminate, one's oil platforms. The first player to make $120,000,000 in cash is the winner.

16906.name: Auction
16906.description:
Players attempt to “furnish a home” as quickly as possible by acquiring furniture cards at “auction” or at “shop prices.” They must also sell furniture by auction.

“Rent” has to be paid players acquire the required kitchen and bedroom furniture cards. Furnishing a second bedroom produces rental income from a “lodger”.

The winner is the first player to have acquired a full set of furniture cards plus one other item.

16907.name: Pol-A-Tics
16907.description: In "Pol-A-Tics", each player is assigned a platform of seven different issues that shows which position their candidate has taken on each issue. As with many election games, players choose a game duration prior to the start of game play. When that time has expired, players determine the popular vote winner in each state to allocate the electoral votes. Unlike actual elections, however, a tie in the popular vote for a state results in a split of that state's electoral votes, and the player with the most electoral votes is declared the winner.

16908.name: Politics As Usual
16908.description:
In "Politics as Usual", each player takes on the role of a U.S. Senator and competes at getting himself/herself re-elected to the Senate. A player needs 5,000,000 votes in order to be re-elected. To gain these votes, players will need to cooperate with each other to pass Pork Barrel legislation and gain voter support, as well as work on their own to raise money.

The box cover illustrates some of the rather humorous cards in the game, some of which play off of events contemporaneous to the game's design. In one example, a player gains 700,000 votes due to their "Trial Reform" bill which, in actuality, creates a casino in the player's state "specializing in bets on outcomes of celebrity murder trials."

16909.name: Praise the Loot???
16909.description: "Praise the Loot???" is a product of the mid-1980s, when at least one prominent televangelist was found using his fun raising abilities for somewhat less than evangelical goals. In this game, 2-6 players race to the Pearly Gates. However, instead of amassing virtues - or even converts - the victor must acquire sufficient money and possessions in order to win.

16910.name: Presidential Fever
16910.description:
"Presidential Fever" allows players to face off against each other in a two Party contest. Two to four players may compete, though the three player game essentially calls for one player on one side to fill both the Presidential and Vice-Presidential roles. Players move around the board, capturing states with campaign funds. Players must also watch to maintain their credibility rating and to build either a liberal or conservative rating when appropriate. A lack of credibility keeps your party from winning a state; high credibility allows your party to overcome a liberal or conservative bias; liberal or conservative leanings provide financial rewards in many states.

Unlike most games based on the Electoral College system, Presidential Fever combines a number of contiguous low value states into a single region (e.g., Farm Belt, Border States, Mid-Atlantic, Deep South, etc.).

16911.name: Profit & Loss
16911.description:
Now here's a game from 1977 with a relatively short title and a mouthful of a game maker's name. The game is Profit & Loss ; the maker is Hollow Stump Bungalow Books & Games.

As the name suggests, two to six players buy and sell various items (antiques, art, securities, real estate, collectibles, etc.), trying to achieve a profit on each one. However, victory goes to the first player to reach $1,000,000, so at the end of the game it may be worthwhile to dump items at a loss to reach the finish first.

16912.name: Pure Greed
boardgameimplementation: Speculation: The Dynamic Real Estate Auction Game
16912.description:
In 1971, CreaTek release a title called "Pure Greed" and subtitled it as, "A Nasty Game for Nasty People." In truth, the game could have been subtitled, "A Nasty Game *from* Nasty People," as it is essentially the same game that CreaTek marketed a few years earlier under the name "Speculation".

"Pure Greed" is for two to six players. The object of the game is to amass the greatest wealth through property ownership. Players first compete at auction for the properties, then collect rents from each other or the bank as they land on owned properties. The game ends when the last purchase OPTION card has been purchased, at which point the player with the most money is the winner.

16913.name: Running For President
16913.description: "Running For President" is a game that provides an odd mix of Primary, Convention, and General Election campaigns. Each player must obtain the necessary vote total in the Primary area in order to proceed to the Convention, then a higher vote total to proceed to the General Election, then a still higher vote total to break free and try to end the game. The player with the highest vote total wins, regardless of where they are on the board.

16914.name: Shrieks & Creaks
16914.description: "Shrieks & Creaks" is a cassette-driven game featuring a Talking Tombstone. Players move from room to room and use both the room keys and their own character key to try to advance. A tombstone-shaped speaker attaches to a standard cassette player. The speaker will only allow sounds through if the right combination of room and character key are put into it. If sounds come from the speaker, the corresponding room is blocked to that player.

16915.name: Slick Willie
16915.description:
Long before Monica Lewinsky and cigars came to the fore on Clinton-based games, "Slick Willie" was a common theme in the Clinton-based game fare. As the designer goes on to note in his introduction, "This game is based solely on my opinion. It's designed to make you laugh at all the hard times we've had over taxation and for all the aggravation, desperation and suffering we're all going to share in the months and years ahead."

In light of the game having come out before Clinton finished his first year in office, the prior 12 years of Republican presidencies, and the subsequent U.S. economic boom, it comes across in hindsight as one of the more mean-spirited Clinton games to hit the market.

The game is nominally for two to four players, though the designer notes that, "you may play up to 6 players, for extra pawns use lose [sic] change." The object of the game is to amass and retain 270 electoral votes while trying to enter the White House.

16916.name: The Big Board
16916.description:
From the game description:

"THE BIG BOARD is a game of stock investments, combining chance and skill. Two to six players move colored tokens around the board, and play the market. The object of the game is to make money, as much money as possible, before the game ends. To do this, players SPECULATE, buying low priced stocks that may rise in value, PROFIT-TAKE, selling stocks for more than they cost, and EARN DIVIDENDS on the stock they own. [...]

"Investors must watch the market's movement and make the right choice at the right time to get the most return on their investments. Test your skill against the ups and downs of the stock market on THE BIG BOARD."

16917.name: The Big Campaign
16917.description: "The Big Campaign" is a game for either two or four players. In a fashion reminiscent of Monopoly, players gain the electoral votes of a given state by landing on it and buying it. Opponents who land on one of your states must pay a penalty for campaigning in that state. However, there are Campaign issue cards that can allow you to gain a state for free, or have a state wrested from your control and placed back up for grabs.

16919.name: The Mileage Game
16919.description: In The Mileage Game, players compete in trying to travel the greatest number of miles using the least number of gas tokens. The game ends when one player has traveled 2000 miles; however, the winner is the player who has achieved the best Miles Per Gallon (MPG) score.

16920.name: The Narc Game
16920.description:
"The Narc Game" strikes an unusual, and perhaps unintentional, balance between the blatantly drug-sympathetic "Dealer McDope" and the "just say no" approach of "Decisions". From the lid description above, it would appear to be a strictly anti-drug game. Yet, curiously, actual game play comes across more as a "beat the system" game than one of social value education.

Two to six players compete, with the object of the game being to accumulate the fewest arrests. The game ends when all players have successfully made it from the "START" square to the "HOME" square. Along the way, players gain and lose money in various drug deals, and must try to avoid a stint in the Criminal Justice system that costs them money and sends them back to "START".

The joke of the game, of course, is that it is almost impossible to go from START to HOME without getting sent back to START.

16921.name: Traffic Jam
16921.description: In "Traffic Jam", players try to reach their respective chosen destinations with a combination of both strategic road sign placement and good die rolls.

16922.name: Gekitsui oh
16922.description:
This is an Japanese air combat game set in the Pacific during World War 2.

"Geki tsui oh" means "Flying Ace" (word to word: "Shooting down aircraft expert").

16923.description:
This is a Japanese wargame set during the time of the Romance of the Three Kingdoms era in Chinese history.

the game is a first attempt to this theme in wargame format in Japan.
And very famous one for its own sake.
At game starts, players pick three character counters randomly.
Yes, this is the "Oath at Peach Garden" for each player.
Game include over 100 characters.
So, the game is basically a "Grow fast" type multi players game.
16923.name: Romance of the Three Kingdoms
boardgameexpansion: Romance of the Three Kingdoms Expansion Kit

16924.name: Helios
boardgameversion: Polygon Corporation North American Championship Edition
16924.description:
Helios (subtitled "The Game of the Gods") is a chess-like game loosely inspired by classical mythology.

The "king" for each side is Helios, the sun god, and nine other pieces on each side represent the planets and the gods they are named after. Three other pieces on each side represent Earth's Moon and its orbital nodes. The pieces are made of a plastic called Tenite (according to the rulebook) and resemble chess pieces topped with the traditional planetary symbols.

The pieces have movement powers reminiscent of those of chess pieces, but with some differences: several pieces have more than one way to move, one mode of movement - N squares at a time in any direction, repeated 3 times - is not found in standard chess, and generally speaking pieces are limited to moving a number of spaces equal to their relative position from the Sun plus 1 (e.g., the Earth piece can move 4 squares at a time).

The board is a 20x20 grid with a block of 40 unplayable spaces in the center. There are special starred spaces on the board which are used by the pieces with weaker standard movement (Mercury and Helios) to teleport around the board.

Pieces are captured by landing on them. The object is to put the opponent's Helios in checkmate (or "total eclipse").

In addition to the rules themselves, the rulebook includes information on the gods and planets represented by the pieces.

16925.name: Sailboat Race Game
boardgamepublisher: Tee Pee Toys, Jessup Paper Box Co.
16925.description: Simple roll and move game for boys and girls Ages 4 - 8

16926.name: Super Plug
16926.description:
"You don't know the power of the plug!"

Cards and rules in an envelope, following the Cheapass design philosophy. The premise is that the players are trying to get the landlord's attention by plugging up the toilet in their apartment with anything they can find on the theory that, while the toilet is being fixed all the other things wrong with the apartment will be fixed also. Having lived in off-campus apartments during college, I can relate.

Each player is given a playing mat with a picture of a toilet on it and is dealt one card. On each player's turn they may draw from 0-2 cards and play one card, either on their own toilet or another player's. The winner is the first person to exactly reach a predetermined level of points worth of stuff in their toilet (20 points for a two player game, 18 for three, etc.) Some cards are worth negative points and are played on opponents. That person must then remove that many points worth of stuff from their toilet. If they don't have any cards small enough (say a -2 card was played, for instance) they must discard a larger card (Baby Brother [+5] for instance) and accept the greater loss--no making change allowed. There are also Pet cards. While a player has a Pet card next to their toilet they cannot win even if their toilet is full to the required score--the landlord doesn't allow pets. They may discard the Pet card, but this counts as their entire action for the turn and they may not draw or play any other cards.

Each copy of Super Plug also comes with 5 blank cards. Players are encouraged to create cards of their own.

16927.description:
This is a Japanese wargame on the Nanboku-cho period and simulates one of the most dynamic and important periods in Japanese history.

It uses an area movement system. This game has cult status among Japanese wargamers as one of the best games representing the era, and the system is also used in the designer's later games Koetsu gunki and Warriors of God.

Components (First edition):

1 Rule book
1 Map (510x360 mm)
1 Counter sheet (128 Counters)
8 Six side dice
16927.name: Taiheiki

16929.name: View-Master Grand Prix
16929.description:
The game is played on a 4’ x 3’ board depicting a race track. The track has grid spaces on it and players roll dice to move (one space for each number).

If a car lands on a space with a picture on it, the player has to pick up the Viewmaster viewer and place a reel in it. They then roll a die and advance the reel by the number shown. Peering in the viewer, they will see a 3D scene that will either give them an advantage or a handicap.

The game came with four Matchbox cars; these are now very rare collectibles.

16930.name: Små kloka barn på piratäventyr
16930.description:
The little smart pirate shall go from the sinking ship to the island there the pirates treasure is located. On his way to the island the pirate has to answer some questions. The right answer can give him one or several gold-coins. But on his way there is also dangerous things that want to stop the pirate from reaching the island. Like the dreadful pirate captain, the evil octapussy and the hungry shark.
The pirate with the most gold is the winner

16931.description:
Hydra! (subtitled "The Ultimate Starcruiser?") was one of Grenadier's "Midi Games" (sic) or "The Great Little Games Line," depending on whether you believe the box or the rules. This was a small line of games somewhat larger than a typical mini-game of the day.

Hydra! could reasonably be described as "Ogre in Space." As in Ogre one player has a single huge unit while the other has many small units. Here the large unit is the eponymous Hydra, which has phasers, proton torpedoes, energy sapper discs, a gyro-de-stabilizer, a molecular structure distorter, and a force field projector. The other player gets frigates, battle cruisers, larger battle cruisers, and mine sweepers. Damage for both sides is marked off on record sheets.

The Hydra player's goal is simply to destroy as many enemy ships as possible, but players are invited to make up other scenarios and some extra counters are provided to facilitate this.

7001 in the "Great Little Games Line". The back of the first (only?) printing's box came with the sheet for the game "Journey" and listed its part number also as #7001. This same sheet also came with the actual game "Journey" as well. However, the sides of the boxes had Hydra! as 7001 and Journey as 7002.
16931.name: Hydra!: The Ultimate Starcruiser?

16932.name: Starcross
16932.description:
Starcross is a relatively simple strategic science fiction game.

The board is made up of a number of hexagonal sections, the number in use depending on the number of players and the desired length of the game. Each section has a number of star systems which produce varying amounts of credit, and have no other characteristics. Players use their controlled credit each turn to build or upgrade their ships.
Ships have two characteristics, movement speed and combat strength - players choose the values of these by how much they spend.

Interest is added by the technological advances which can be purchased. Some of these are permanent, such as Hyperdrive, which lets one ship per turn move an unlimited distance, or Capture, which lets you capture enemy ships if you have a 3:1 advantage, while some are temporary, such as Force Field, which protects a system for one turn. (Capture will sound familiar to players of Flying Buffalo's Starweb play-by-mail game - most of the Starweb abilities are in fact reproduced here.) Each advance can only be purchased a given number of times per game (depending on the number of players), so players will be forced to use different mixes of abilities.

The object of the game is to control a given quantity of credit production.

16933.description:
Publisher's Description

Fly through the city. Smash the villains. Backstab your teammates and grab their gadgets.

Munchkin has parodied the classic dungeon, the kung-fu warrior, the space epic, and the creatures of the night. Now, it's the superheroes' turn!

Be a Mutant, an Exotic, a Mystic, or a Techno. The higher your Level, the more Powers you can have. Battle dastardly masterminds, devastating monsters, and invading aliens from the next dimension - from the wimpy Triplicate Twit all the way up to Big Ol' Planet Eater Guy himself - and TAKE THEIR STUFF! With the Aura Helmet, the Telezapinator, and the (jet-powered) Pogo Stick, no foe can stand before you.

Super Munchkin is a stand-alone game, which (of course) can be combined with other Munchkin games. Designed by Steve Jackson (I) and illustrated by John Kovalic, this one is destined to RULE THE WORLD! Mwahahaha!


Other

Part of the Munchkin series

Munchkin is a satirical card game based on the clichés and oddities of Dungeons and Dragons and other role-playing games. Each player starts at level 1 and the winner is the first player to reach level 10. Players can acquire familiar D&D style character classes during the game which determine to some extent the cards they can play.

There are two types of cards - treasure and encounters. Each turn the current players 'kicks down the door' - drawing an encounter card from the deck. Usually this will involve battling a monster. Monsters have their own levels and players must try and overcome it using the levels, weapons and powers they have acquired during the game or run away. Other players can chose to help the player or hinder by adding extra monsters to the encounter. Defeating a monster will usually result in drawing treasure cards and acquiring levels. Being defeated by a monster results in "bad stuff" which usually involves losing levels and treasure.
16933.name: Super Munchkin
boardgameexpansion: Munchkin Get More Loot! Promotional Postcard
Munchkin Sparkly Good Fairy Shot Glass
Super Munchkin 2: The Narrow S Cape

16934.name: Captain Kidd's Treasure
16934.description:
The object of the game is to move your ship from one Treasure corner of the board to any other Treasure corner. Instead of using a die to dictate movement, the game uses a shuttered Light House "spinner". Players rotate the light house wheel in either direction until a dot appears. Opening the shutter at this point reveals a "light" that tells how many spaces the ship may move.

Some strategy comes into play, as circle spaces at the board's pathway intersections confer both advantages and disadvantages. A ship on a circle space *must* turn left or right on its next turn, but a player whose ship on a circle may move another player's ship if that move will put his opponent on a circle space.

boardgamehonor: 2001 Årets Spel Best Children's Game Winner
16935.name: Små kloka upptäcker rymden
16935.description:
The task for the little smart astronaut to take his spaceship as fast as he can to the moon.
The journey is filled with tricky questions. The answers will be rewarded with stars. The stars can be used to buy extra fuel or pay fines if he took the wrong way.

First to the moon is the winner.

16936.description:
This is a self-published game that can be downloaded for free at several sites over the Internet (including the designer's site, so this is not a violation of any type).

From the introduction in the rulebook:

"Napoleon at Chattanooga is a painstakingly-researched, meticulously accurate simulation of Napoleon's campaign in the Tennessee Valley. It is also a two-player game of exploration and conquest in the Solar System, which is also painstaking but not necessarily accurate. This game is the first in the ACW (Advanced Chart Wars) series and is also considered part of the ongoing GBoTGCN (Great Battles of This Guy Called Napoleon) series by most of the people working in the stockroom."
16936.name: Napoleon at Chattanooga

16937.name: Basic Training
16937.description:
"Basic Training is played on a small hex-based map that represents a section of New Guinea. The playing pieces represent companies of Australian Army and Japanese Army soldiers. Each player moves and attacks with his units, in turn, in an attempt to capture (or prevent from being captured) the Village hexes shown on the map. The Japanese player is attempting to capture at least two villages, and the Australian player is trying to prevent him from doing this."

Contents - a booklet containing:
- 10 unmounted counters (4 Australian, 6 Japanese)
- 1 unmounted 68-hex mapboard
- 1 combat results table
- 3 pages of basic rules
- 1 page of optional rules
- 2 pages of examples

16938.name: Googolplex
16938.description: 36 tiles make up this maze game with a twist. The preprinted maze on the tiles show you the path to the other side. If you come to a dead end, your turn ends. On your next turn, you turn a tile and continue on your path. A very clever game with no dice, cards, or spinners.

16939.name: Torpedo Game
16939.description:
Summary from the box ...

"It's a fast paced battle at sea. It's an action packed game for the whole family."

Instructions (from box lid) ...

"To Set Up
Each player places six of the steel balls in the loading slot of his torpedo gun. Each player sets up three ships in the notches at his end of the game board.

To Play
The object is to knock over the opponent's ships with the torpedoes (the steel balls). First, turn the torpedo tubes to the direction of the enemy ship, by using the target finder through which you can sight the ship. Then, fire the torpedoes by pressing the trigger. Players may rotate turns or fire simultaneously. Each player totals his score for the ships he has sunk. 100 is a perfect score."

16941.description: This is a Japanese wargame on ground combat in the anime world of Gundam Zeta, this game focuses on the battles of the AEUG faction (the good guys).
16941.name: Gundam Zeta A.E.U.G.
boardgameexpansion: Mobile Suit Z Gundam: Gate of Zedan

16943.name: Pokémon Battle Disc Competition
16943.description:
From the Rulebook:

Select and shuffle up to FOUR Battle Discs at a time. Place them into the plastic ball and shake it. Open it and "slam down" the ball-half containing the discs. The other players do the same. Once all the players have their pile of discs in front of them the battle begins.

Each player places the discs in a straight line in the order that they have come out of the plastic ball. Place the matching figure next to the disc.

Starting with the first disc, each player flips their disc into the air. How it lands determines who "wins the battle" and puts the other player's figures out of the competition. The disc with the greatest power rating (number of stars) wins. A tie of the highest numbers has to be flipped again until there is a winner.

Play continues until all the figures are defeated except for the remaining one who is the champion.

boardgamehonor: 2002 Mensa Select Winner
16944.description:
Add, subtract, multiply, and/or divide three (3) numbers shown on the dice to produce an answer. Try to make an answer that helps build and run for you (bonus points) or blocks your opponent's run. Throw in a bluff or challenge your opponent's answer as you try to outwit and outmaneuver each other in this analytical aerobic workout for the mind!

http://www.educationallearninggames.com/how-to-play-muggins-...

2002 Mensa Select

Re-implemented as:

Opps
16944.name: Muggins!

16945.name: Knock-Out
16945.description:
Add three numbers together to make a total. Then use your best thinking skills to break that total into its parts to knock your opponents off the board while capturing numbers for yourself! From the mathematically challenged to the mathematically gifted, KNOCK-OUT!, with its multi-leveled play, is guaranteed to make math fun again!

http://www.educationallearninggames.com/how-to-play-muggins-...

16946.name: Super 12
16946.description:
Super 12 is based on 12 meter yacht racing. Up to six yacht pieces move around a board designed as a sailing race course.

Players are dealt cards and must predict the number of a particular "suit" the other players hold. When a prediction is made other players may raise the prediction or call - by playing a protest penalty card. Winners of each round advance around a sailing course board. Losing protesters go back a space.

16947.name: Monkey Trouble
16947.description:
A huge catastrophe has happened during the reception that the Countess organized in her garden! Koko the little monkey has escaped and stolen panties and other sexy underwear from the drying line. Here he is, giving them to the guests who are shocked by this dreadful vision !

The Countess is beside herself and orders her servant to quickly do something otherwise he will be fired. But Alfred is too old to catch the monkey ! So he decides to ask the many participants to go into the living room after he gets back the panties that are being given out Koko. Hopefully when he eventually catches Koko, he will be able to get several pairs of underwear back simultaneously. Anyway he’ll have to make sure that at 5 o’clock, no more guest still has a piece of underwear in hand or he loses his job.

16948.description:
Beetles tree putting play game, with several play variants. Good for 2 players. Beetles have to get cherries, but there are not enough for all players. It becomes particularly exciting, if the luck beetles come into the play!

Contents: 1 three-part tree, 12 beetles, 2 luck beetles, 10 yellow and 10 green plugs, to 6 valuation disks (everything in wood)

Ages 3 and up
16948.name: Glücks-Käfer-Baum

16949.name: Matchbox Traffic Game
16949.description:
Each player has a Matchbox car which is moved on the board. Players travel between destinations to accumulate mileage. The center of the board features a rotating turntable and rotating traffic signal. The turntable changes "shortcut" paths across the center of the board when it rotates, the traffic signal changes game play.

Ages 8 - 14

The original game included two Matchbox cars; examples of the game that still include the cars and the boxes are highly collectible.

16950.name: Tokugawa Ieyasu
16950.description: This is a Japanese wargame on the famous battles of Tokugawa Ieyasu, the Shogun who founded the Tokugawa shogunate when he won the battle of Sekigahara.

16951.description:
The theme is the Genpei war (1180-1185) leading to birth of the first Shogunate, Genji or Minamoto.

The game was designed by Makoto Nakajima of "Taiheiki" fame.
The system was derived from that game and can be played in 30 minutes.
16951.name: Genpei War: Rise and Fall

16952.name: The Big Match Football Game
16952.description: Game of Australian Rules Football. The Big Match Football Game from 1991 closely simulates the real thing. Role the dice and move the football down the field by hand or foot. Marks are contested, scores kicked, tackles laid, free kicks given, ball-ups ruled, reports made etc.. Tackle cards and play cards provide the umpires decision on contests.

16953.description:
(From the BrickMech site:)

BrickMech is a d6-based game where Mechs built of LEGO® bricks vie for ultimate control of the battlefield. Constructed in a unique modular system, Mechs can scavenge parts blown off other Mechs to improve their stats. The game is designed to be a rich gaming experience that's simple to play.
16953.name: BrickMech

16954.name: Lucky Town
16954.description: 1946 game from Milton Bradley. A simple roll and move game. Also known as the Build a Happy Home Game.

16955.name: Orient Expedition
16955.description: Use game cards and board pieces with your Orient Expedition LEGO sets to overcome challenges, defeat villains and discover hidden treasure. Each player controls a unique LEGO character, with specific speed, luck, and strength attributes. Move around the board, collecting items to enhance your character's abilities so that you can overcome obstacles. Combat LEGO villains that stand in your way. The challenges and obstacles are essentially a scripted "Indiana Jones" type storyline. When you have overcome the final challenge, all players win. You can rearrange your game board and sets to create all-new adventures.

16956.name: The Sweeney
16956.description:
It has a yellow and black duo-toned drawing of Regan and Carter on the box, and claims to be 'an exciting game for four players'.

The game parts are: a board, a scoreboard, 16 small cards and 4 small plastic figures representing The Villains (typical Burgler Bill 'swag' type figures) and The Sweeney (Policeman blowing a whistle). Oh, and two dice.

The idea is that you work in pairs, two players are the villains, and two are The Sweeney. You have to meet up with your partner at randomly designated places on the board for a raid. When you successfully raid a location you get points to add to the scoreboard, and the winner is the first up the scoreboard to number 14.

boardgamedesigner: Georg Heinrich Leopold Freiherrn von Reisswitz
Georg Heinrich Rudolf Johann Baron von Reiswitz
16957.description:
A 1983 translation into English and reprint of the original Prussian Kriegspiel map wargame. The book includes all the tables and charts needed to play as well as cardboard units to be cut out and a terrain map for a small battle. Leeson's translation includes some elements from later developments in the game, until about 1870, when the "Rigid Kriegspiel" (rules-based) of Von Reisswitz gave way to the "Free Kriegspiel" system (based on the umpire's judgment and experience). The aim of the rules is well described by the subtitle "Instructions for the Representation of Military Maneuvers with Kriegspiel Apparatus."

The book has been reprinted by Too Fat Lardies in 2007.
boardgameversion: Scan of the original German edition from 1824
16957.name: Kriegsspiel
boardgameexpansion: Rules for the Conduct of the War-Game

16958.name: The Nags Head Board Game (Only Fools and Horses)
16958.description:
Mange Tout Rodney, get down the apple & pears, get your cocktail umbrella & jellied eels ready 'cos you won't believe your mince pies when you see what's going down in the Nag's Head pub.

Yes, it's time for a knees up in the Nag's head. Meet the gang at the bar, choose a character & be the first to collect all the drinks. On the way, avoid being barred & take a chance on the quiz night or, if you're feeling lucky, try one of Del's Dares.....he who dares...wins!

Your amazing Nag's Head Game Collector's Tin contains:
x1 playing board, x1 dice, x1 bag, x6 character playing tokens, x6 character game cards, x20 happy hour cards, x36 drink tokens, x20 Del's dares cards

16959.description:
Roll the dice and move around the board. When you land on an Angelina Ballerina space, draw a dance card, and then stand up and perform the depicted ballet step or position. The first person to collect 4 dance cards wins, but first they must perform a ballet routine using all 4 steps or positions shown on their cards.
Also includes a "Memory" variant in the rules, using the dance cards.
16959.name: Angelina Ballerina's Dancing Game

16960.description: This is a collection of variants of 4 popular card games with an Angelina Ballerina theme. Included are themed variants of: Memory, Crazy 8s, Go Fish, and Spoons.
16960.name: Angelina's Dress-Up Card Game

16961.description: Players spin to claim the objects that match their playing board. The first to get all 7 is the winner.
16961.name: Maisy Game

16962.name: Bouncin' Bunnies
16962.description: Load different small colored plastic bunnies into the game board and turn it on. The board rotates, and the bunnies randomly pop/hop/bounce up several feet into the air, while the players try to catch them in hand held baskets. Different colored bunnies are worth different numbers of points, so players must choose to either compete for the rare high valued bunnies, or grab a lot of the lower valued bunnies instead.

16963.name: Bug Bingo
16963.description: A humorous bug themed variant of Bingo, where players roll two dice and cover any of the pictures on their cards that match the images shown on both dice. Certain die rolls force pictures to be uncovered. Get all four corners covered, or four-in-a-row in any direction, and you win.

16964.name: Sight Words Bingo
16964.description: A Bingo variant where squares are covered when the player hears or sees a matching reading "sight word" revealed. Provides practice for beginning readers to recognize 46 common words like "the", "when", "to", "is", etc.

16965.description: A collection of three games, where kids search for treasures, collect silver and gold, or match colorful fish on the playing board. Intended to exercise and reinforce basic math counting and pattern recognition skills.
16965.name: 1, 2, 3 Treasures in the Sea

16966.name: Cammy
16966.description:
Cammy is a Yahtzee variant that tries to evoke a "Southern feel" by stating in the rules that it was played on southern plantations and later by New Orleans gamblers. It also has a steamboat scene on the cover. It is different from Yahtzee mainly by the fact that 10 dice are used, and the low score wins.
Players roll 10 dice on the first roll. On the second roll they choose which of the dice to re-roll. Same on the third roll. After 3 rolls the 10 dice are divvied up into two groups of 5 dice. Each player has a sheet of paper with 10 categories. Players choose a category to score with each of the 2 groups. Each category must be finished after the player's fifth turn.

16967.name: Il Corsaro Nero
16967.description:
Nine cargo ships (with diverse, hidden cargo values) try to escape from three pirate ships (black, green and red) in the Caribbean sea.

Ships are moved in turns (3 cargo ships, black pirate ship, 3 cargo ship, green pirate ship, 3 cargo ships, red pirate ship) drawing wind cards from a deck. Each card shows wind direction and strength, and ships are moved accordingly.

Game end as soon as all cargo ships are captured or successfully escapes from the Caribbean sea.

The one who captured/saved more cargo value is the winner.

16969.name: Hunch
16969.description: Take Chinese Checkers, sprinkle with penalty features, "stay put" handicaps, and a blind color selector and you have Hunch! Like its name, your success depends on how right your hunches are. You stay still, go forward, or go backward depending on the colors underneath the marbles, which the players select themselves using the Hunch Dial.

16970.description:
Barnacity is near E-X-P-L-O-S-I-O-N!

Fanhunter Battles is a boardgame where bloody urban combats between Papal Troops from Alejo I and brave hordes of Resistence Fans that opposing the Alejo I Pope, in the near Future and comic world of Fanhunter.

A system game for idiot proven gamers, 8 modular boards, tons of tiles and chits, 6 scenarios ready to play, a language that scanal your parents. Fanhunter includes everything for starting the war in the streets of Barnacity.

This time it is the war...

Expanded by:

Fanhunter: Suburbia Expansion
16970.name: Fanhunter Batallitas

16971.description:
Expansion for the game Fanhunter Battles.

It allows to expand the world of Fanhunter, adding new troops and big Guys.
16971.name: Fanhunter: Suburbia Expansion

16972.description:
Alexandria, 1801 is the first part of SimTac´s series "Battles of the Revolution & the Empire" on tactical (battalion, squadron, battery) level and medium/low complexity. You get two Battles in this box : the Battle of Mandara fought on March 13th and the Battle of Canope was fought on March 21st 1801 between the French L´Armée d´Orient and the British Invasion Army under Sir Ralph Abercromby. The basic rules for this game/series are much easier and faster to learn and more simple as SimTac´s other series: "Battles of the Peninsular War" but you can play this game also with the more detailed rules of the Battles of the Peninsular War when you own Los Arapiles or Saguntum. The game contains:

- one 24" x 20" mounted(!)map
- 216 die- cut counter
- 1 basic- and 1 special rulebook
- two orders of battle, player-aid card, morale level charts
- two ten-sided dice
16972.name: Alexandria, 1801

16973.name: Genial daneben: Das Spiel
16973.description:
This game is based on a German television show.
In the show famous people are trying to guess the right answers for questions that we stumble over everyday, but nobody ever tried to think of the why's and how's.
E.g. where did a certain idiom originate.
It's pretty funny to watch the players discuss their ideas and interesting to finally hear the answer.

In this board game, contrary to the show, there are three possible answers given to each question.
Players should discuss the given "answers" and each come to a conclusion, placing a chip on marked areas on the board.
The players who guessed right get points, the game master gets points for every wrong answer.

Expanded by:

Genial daneben: Das Spiel – Zusatzfragen

16974.name: Schnappi, das kleine Krokodil
16974.description:
In this game "Schnappi" (a little green crocodile that became famous due to a children's song that made it into the charts) wants to seek rest and go to sleep in the middle of the board.
It's the goal of the players to move Schnappi over obstacles and finally into the middle of the board.

16975.name: Teen Titans Collectible Card Game
16975.description: A collectible card game based on the Cartoon Network cartoon version of the Teen Titans. Each player uses the Titans and other characters from the show to amass "equilibrium points". The first player to 20 wins.

16976.name: Knights of the Zodiac Collectible Card Game
16976.description: A collectible card game based on the Knights of the Zodiac animated series. Players try to defeat their opponents knight cards in battle or "take control of" field cards to amass 20 victory points and win a "contest". The first player to win two contests wins the game.

16977.description:
From WotC Press Release:

CODENAME: KIDS NEXT DOOR TCG players start with a deck of cards featuring the five agents on 5 different color cards. On their turn, players decide if they want to engage in a face-off competition using their top card, or instead place that card into the Kids Next Door's tree house headquarters. Cards placed in the tree house help boost the power of cards that are played in future face-offs.

When cards are played in a face-off, the player with the higher number (which may get boosted by a card banked in the tree house) wins the round. The first player to win 5 rounds wins the game, ensuring an entire game can be played in five minutes or less.

And what happens when each player plays a same-colored card? Both players race to be the first to slap a giant panic button placed on the playing mat to determine the round's winner.
16977.name: Codename: Kids Next Door Trading Card Game

16978.name: Combino
16978.description:
The game consists of a board and two dice; one with numbers 1 - 6 and one with cartoons (car - boat - train - cat - bird - pig). The board has 36 squares with holes in the middle. Every square is a combination of the dice (train + 1, pig + 4, etc.).

Throw the dice and see what combination comes up. Players try to find the combination on the board and whoever is first pins his colored pawn in that square. Winner is the one who pinned all his pawns in.

16979.description:
Secret training of the "Wilden Fußballkerle".

But where are they? First you have to find two characters from the team and then they must score a penalty.

Sounds easy, buy it's not, with Markus the goalkeeper and the Damp-Hammer-Chip playing against you!

One with a good memory and one who is able to prove his dexterity with the penalties will win the secret training.
16979.name: DampfHammerHart

16981.description: Your goal is to be the first player to reach the Castle at Cair Paravel. Along the way, you’ll encounter the White Witch and her minions of nasty dwarfs. But you’ll be cheered on by the boosts of the friendly beavers, as well as the benevolent presence of the Great Lion, Aslan. Cooperative play is part of the action because once the White Witch captures a player, the rest must move backwards until someone intercedes with an Aslan card. The pitfalls are balanced by the shortcuts, but the true of heart will surely lead the way.
16981.name: The Lion and the White Witch

16982.name: Fun House
16982.description: Based on the 1980s kids game show of the same name, 2-3 players/teams play several "skill games" involving the games components (such as a mini ramp, golf club, etc) and answer questions for spaces on the board. First player/team to reach the finish wins.

16983.name: Mission Impossible
16983.description: Dating from the original 1970's Mission Impossible TV series, the aim of this board game is to try and discover the identity of your 'target', and blow his cover, and eliminate him - before one of your opponents does the same to you. The sole surviving agent at the end of the game is the winner.

16984.name: Gunfight at OK Corral
16984.description:
This is a children's dexterity game where players have a real-time shootout. The board is a long plastic tray flanked with colorful western town inserts. At each end of the tray is a plastic six-shooter (one for each player) that are attached so that they can move freely across the width of the board. The guns are loaded with ball bearings on the top. A slide comes out the bottom and ends flush with the playing surface where a plastic cowboy is attached. When you pull the trigger, a ball rolls down the slide, goes through the legs of the cowboy and shoots across the tray toward your opponent's side. Each plastic cowboy has a tab by its feet that acts as a target. Hit it with a "bullet" and the cowboy gets knock down "dead". The fist player to shoot the other player's cowboy wins. Each player has a rock and a cactus to use as cover. The trick is that you have to be out in the open (and taking careful aim) to shoot, but also dodging left and right to avoid your opponent's fire.

This game is similar to Crossfire.

boardgameimplementation: Der Goldene Kompass: Das Kartenspiel zum Film
boardgamehonor: 2005 Fairplay À la carte Winner
16985.description:
Gelb gewinnt! is based on the Italian game Scopa; Kosmos described it as Scopa in German style.

The game consists of two deck of cards, each consisting of 10 yellow cards and 30 blue cards, valued 1-10. In addition, 80 victory point chips are included.

Each round is played as follows: the dealer will deal each player three cards. Four cards are played on the table, open. The players now take turns playing cards. On each turn, a player can play exactly one card. A player can use this card to capture a number of cards on the table. Cards can be captured if the sum of those cards is equal to the card played (i.e. you can capture a six and a two by playing an eight). If a player cannot capture any cards, he has to add a card to those open on the table. A player gets one point for capturing all cards on the table.

The round lasts until all players have played their three hand cards. Now, each player receives points: One point for the player who has captured the yellow seven, one point for the player who has captured the most yellow cards and one point for the player who has captured the most cards.

The play continues for a couple of rounds (either six rounds for two or three players, or a number of rounds equal to the number of players if there are four or more players. In the end, the player who has collected the most points wins.
16985.name: Gelb gewinnt!

boardgamehonor: 2003 Årets Spel Best Family Game Winner
2005 International Gamers Awards - General Strategy; Multi-player Nominee
2005 Japan Boardgame Prize Best Foreign Game for Beginners
2005 Kinderspielexperten "8-to-13-year-olds" Nominee
2005 Kinderspielexperten "8-to-13-year-olds" Winner
2005 Spiel der Spiele Hit für Familien Recommended
2007 Vuoden Peli Family Game of the Year Nominee
2007 Vuoden Peli Family Game of the Year Winner
2008 Årets Spill Best Family Game Nominee
2008 Årets Spill Best Family Game Winner
2008 Juego del Año Finalist
2009 Årets Spel Best Family Game Winner
2011 Guldbrikken Best Family Game Nominee
16986.description:
In Ubongo, players compete to solve individual puzzles as quickly as they can to get first crack at the gems on hand for the taking.

Original edition:
The game board consists of six rows, with twelve gems (of various colors) placed in these rows. At the start of play, each player places his pawn in front of one of those rows. Each player also takes twelve polyominoes — that is, pieces consisting of 2-5 squares in some configuration; players use these pieces each round to try to recreate shapes.

At the start of a round, each player receives a puzzle card that depicts a shape created by some number of squares; one side of this card depicts six rows of 3 pieces, the other side depicts six rows of 4 pieces, for a more difficult puzzle. When everyone is ready, someone rolls a die to determine which row of pieces each player can use to recreate the shape on their individual card. The race is timed by a sand timer, and the outcome of this race determines the action on the main playing board.

Whoever first solves their puzzle in time gets to move their pawn up to three rows left or right, with the second player to finish moving two rows and the third player only one row. Players then collect two gems from the front of the row where their pawn is located, which means that the more rows you can move, the more control you have over which color gems you can collect. After collecting gems, each player receives a new puzzle card, and a new round begins.

After nine rounds, the game ends and whoever has collected the most gems in a single color wins! If players tie, then those players compare who has the most gems in a second color, and so on.

2015 edition:
The puzzle-part of the game remains the same, but the scoring track and system has been greatly changed, to be the same as in Ubongo Extreme. There are no pawns anymore, but instead the winner takes a 3-point gem plus a random gem, the second-place player takes a 1-point gem plus a random gem, and others who finish within time take just a random gem. Whoever scores the most gem-points after nine rounds, wins the game.
16986.name: Ubongo
boardgamepodcastepisode: ET55: Tres Polacos y Un Millón de Elefantes (Segunda parte)
Podcast #043 - Guia de compras y recomendaciones de juegos de mesa 2011 Parte 1
RJ49: Conversa de taverna... parlem de Hearthstone!

16987.description:
Board game for Ages 3 and up

Instead of dice there is a doghouse to push upon; the mummy dog upon it barks 1, 2 or 3 times to tell the children how many steps they can make. So you don't have to seek the dice every time your child has 'thrown' it. Learning to count should be made easier this way.

Goal of the game is to find the 3 bones in the colour of your own puppy dog first. The bones lay spread upside down at random in a circle.

The game is made easy by magnets in the puppy's nose, with witch even very small children can turn around the bone to check if it has their own dogs colour.
16987.name: Diggity Dog

16988.name: Don't Bug Me
16988.description: The object is to get as many matches as possible. You ask other players for bugs that match yours. If they don't have a matching card, they get to shout "Don't Bug Me!". Bug facts are included. Fun and educational game for the kids! Includes 52 game cards.

16989.name: Chilkat: The Indian Warrior Game
16989.description:
Chilkat is a Canadian game about Native Americans and is played on a replica of the ceremonial blanket of the West Coast tribes. Represented on the blanket are 10 symbols which North American Indians used as clan or family crests. These crests were usually inherited or gained by conquest. The more crests, the greater the prestige of the family or chief who displayed them; consequently these titles were very jealously protected.

Using strategy and luck, together with their chiefs and warriors, players will roll the dice for positions, move warriors for offense and defense, and challenge opponents in “fights to the finish” for possession of the symbols on the blanket. The winner is the one whose chiefs control all 10 symbols.

16990.description: Players spin and move around the board finding clues in various rooms. When they find a clue they draw it. When all 3 of Blue's clues are found players attempt guess what the 3 clues are describing.
16990.name: Blue's Clues Game

boardgamehonor: 2006 Golden Geek Best 2-Player Board Game Nominee
2006 Mensa Select Winner
2007 Årets Spel Best Adult Game Winner
2007 Årets Spill Best Family Game Nominee
16991.description:
Khet (a.k.a. Deflexion) is a chess-like board game that has two built in lasers and movable Egyptian-themed game pieces that have embedded mirrors that can be positioned to bounce the laser light around the board and hit opponent pieces.

To play, players alternate moving their pieces around the board. Some pieces have mirrors and some do not. Bounding the board is a raised frame into which are built two low-power lasers, one for each player. The game pieces include a "pharaoh", obelisks, and pyramids with mirrors. After each move, a player must press the button on his/her laser. The beam bounces from mirror to mirror around the playing field. The challenge is to protect one's own pharaoh while maneuvering to "light up" the opposing player's pharaoh.

Reimplemented by

Khet 2.0
boardgameversion: English second edition with inset in box front
Innovention UK Edition with Class 1 Lasers
16991.name: Khet: The Laser Game
boardgameexpansion: Khet: Eye of Horus Beam Splitter

boardgamehonor: 2006 Golden Geek Best Light / Party Game Nominee
16992.description:
From the publisher:

A beautiful and beautifully simple game of laying a tile before your own token to continue its path on each turn. The goal is to keep your token on the board longer than anyone else's, but as the board fills up this becomes harder because there are fewer empty spaces left... and another player's tile may also extend your own path in a direction you'd rather not go. Easy to introduce to new players, Tsuro lasts a mere 15 minutes and actually does work for any number from 2 to 8.

Theme:

Tsuro has an Asian spiritual theme - the lines representing the "many roads that lead to divine wisdom", and the game as a whole representing "the classic quest for enlightenment".

This theme is very light and the game essentially plays as an abstract.

Gameplay:

The game consists of tiles with twisting lines on them, a 6x6 grid on which to lay these tiles and a token for each player. Each player has a hand of tiles. On your turn you do two things: place a tile from your hand onto the board next to your token and move your token as far as it can go along the line it is currently on, until it is stopped by an empty space with no tile in (yet), the edge of the board or colliding with another player's token.
